Artists and designers spend a lot to time looking closely at the things all around them - then showing what they see, with a sketch or a photo. They always first look carefully at the object they want to draw or photograph - to pick up on interesting tiny details. This is called first-hand observation. Primary sources are the things you see yourself, and sketch or photograph yourself. Try sketching some of the things that you see everyday. This will help your powers of observation. Artists always examine what they are going to draw first, so they see those tiny details that might be missed at first glance. The more you look at something, the more detail you will see. Alternatively, you might wish to take inspiration from somewhere that's not home. Take a trip to a different town or city, or maybe visit the countryside. If you are arranging your own subject to draw such as a still-life, then try to make it as visually interesting as possible. For instance when drawing from primary sources you may want to consider creating interesting compositions, drawing to scale, making your own viewfinder or drawing sections and close-ups. (You can read more about viewfinders later in this revision bite.)

A student's preparation sketch work using a viewfinder. Viewfinders are like small windows that allow you to observe a section (small part) of a bigger picture. Viewfinders can be used with paintings, drawings or photographs. When you use a viewfinder, you are concentrating on just one part of a picture that you can then sketch straight into your work journal. It is useful for developing your observational skills, for finding out about scale and to notice those all-important details. You can make your own viewfinder out of a thick piece of card. All you need to do is to cut a large enough hole in the card. Itâ€™s a good idea to put this viewfinder into your work journal. You can attach it to your work journal either by making two holes with a hole-puncher and then threading it into the spirals of the work journal, or just attaching it with a strip of cloth. It will then always be nearby when you need it and also becomes part of your record of work at the end. If you want to see greater detail in your drawing, then you could use a magnifying glass. Always make sure that you are using a free-standing magnifying glass because it's very difficult to hold a magnifying glass and draw at the same time.

A visit to any museum or art gallery will provide you with lots of opportunities to develop ideas and your knowledge and understanding of a subject. If you see something of interest, make some sketches in your work journal, include postcards from the museum shop or images from the museum or gallery website. If you are concentrating on one work of art [art: The expression of creativity or imagination or both. ], then you should make a note of the name of the artist, the title of the piece and the date it was created. The labels next to the work of art may also contain a lot of useful information such as biographical details on the artist, the social context of the work of art and influences on the artist. A student's sketch of an Egyptian artefact While you are in a museum, do not just look at the works of art you came to see. Take some time to look at the other artefacts on display. Artefacts often have interesting design features that might fit in with your coursework. For instance, if you are looking at a certain aspect of African sculpture then there might be some sculpture in the museum display from other parts of the world, or objects from ancient Egypt, that might be inspiring. While you are visiting a museum or gallery take note of how the artworks are grouped together. Artworks are not always grouped in a chronological date order. In some cases, artworks may be grouped by subject or by key art movements. Seeing how artworks can be grouped together should help you to think creatively, and explore different avenues of thought that you might not have considered previously. Georgie visits the Tate Modern Gallery in London to get ideas for her theme.

Brainstorming is an excellent way of exploring your ideas in a visual way. It also shows how your ideas are linked to each other. The best way of doing a brainstorm in your work journal is using what is sometimes called a spidergram or mind map. Spider diagrams (or 'spidergrams') are usually used at the start of a unit of coursework or exam assignment. They allow you to collect together your first thoughts and ideas about a subject so that you can easily see what your intentions are going to be and how you might progress. A student's spidergram drawn during a brainstorming session However, you can use spidergrams at any point in your work journal. This is a good way of showing how your experiences and ideas have developed as you go through your coursework.

Your work journal should include primary sources (your own work) and secondary sources (other people's material from books, magazines, the internet, etc). This Revision Bite will explain more about secondary sources, and show how to use them to make your work journal look good. Secondary sources are images that have already been created by someone else. They will help your observational skills, and develop your understanding of a theme, subject or artist. Secondary sources can include photographs and other images. Just like drawing from primary sources, drawing from secondary sources will develop your observational skills. However, this time it is about examining sources created by another person. No matter what your coursework or examination assignment is, there is a very good chance that other artists have already explored the same themes. Use their works of art to develop your observational skills, to deepen your knowledge and understanding and to create your own ideas. Don't forget that different artists will interpret the same theme in different ways. If your theme is landscapes, then there is a huge difference between the photographs of Ansel Adams and the paintings of the Impressionists. Look at as many examples as you can and make a note of the differences between them. Click on the image to see a bigger version. (If you have Flash, click Magnify to see the detail - to remove the viewfinder just click Magnify again.) The web is a huge resource for research material to include in your work journal. However, there is so much material on the internet that you could waste a lot of time looking for something that you can use in your work journal. Reema talks about how she conducted her secondary research on textile artist Rachel Howard. Before you go onto the web always be clear about exactly what you are looking for. That way you will be able to find it much faster and you can then use the time you have saved to work on other things. If you are going to include text from a website, do not just copy and paste. You should be using your own words to express your ideas and experiences. Read through the text on the website that you are looking at and make some notes of the most important points. Then you can write these main points in your work journal, in any way you like. Don't forget that if you just copy and paste from a website, you are not selecting the information you really need. On top of that, the examiner who looks at your work journal will want to see your work and notes. Copied text from websites is very easy to spot. You can also find vast collections of images on the web that you can include in your work journal. You can save these images by moving the cursor over the image you are interested in, clicking on the right button of the mouse and then scrolling down the menu to 'Save image as'. If you are using a Mac, then just hold the mouse button down until the menu appears. The images of artworks that you research on the internet cannot be included in your final artworks unless you get permission. There's more about copyright later in this Revision Bite: Secondary Sources: Copyright To find out more about how to search for copyright free images, which you can use in your artwork, visit Bitesize DiDA's Revision Bite: Web Research.

If you are photocopying images from a book, cutting out images from a magazine or using an image you have found online, think about whether you need the whole image or just one or more of the details in it. If you only want a few details, then you should crop the picture by cutting out those sections you want to include in your work journal. You can photocopy or print the image out and then cut out the details you want. If it's an online image you could use the cropping tool on any image-editing software, or print it out and then cut it up. For instance, in the photograph above there's a llama on a mountain over-looking Machu Picchu in Peru. You could crop this image to cut out the backdrop so you have the llama only, as shown. Don't fall into the trap of just collecting lots of images to include in your work journal because you can. Before you use any images think about why you need that particular image. Only include an image if there is a good reason for having it.

You should also try to make your work journal visually appealing, so you could use scissors with different cutting edges to create a variety of effects, make use of different coloured pens and so on. In this student's work journal Sharmin has used secondary images of models to model the clothes and patterns she has designed. Remember that the images you create (primary) or use (secondary) can be manipulated, overlaid, annotated and built upon. Don't use secondary images too much - it might look as though you are just trying to fill space. There must always be a reason why you have included something in your work journal. When making use of a secondary image don't forget to read the text that goes with the picture because it will certainly contain information that you can include in your work journal. If you are taking images from a newspaper, then read the news item that goes with the picture and make a note of the important points.

Artists and writers own the copyright for anything they have created. They are protected by copyright law - this prevents other people from copying it without their permission. Copyright law protects anything you can copy - whether it is images or text from books, magazines or the internet. You are allowed to copy images and text for your own private use as long as you do not plan to use it in your own artwork or make any money from it. If you are including secondary sources in your work journal then that's fine - but do acknowledge where you got them from whereever possible. If you are planning to use somebody else's work in your artwork, then you must get permission from whoever owns the copyright. The copyright details are usually included in books and magazines on the front page. For TV programmes you may need to contact the production company. Websites usually have copyright information at the bottom of the webpage. For example if you look at the bottom of the BBC Schools website there is a link that says Schools Copyright (bbc.co.uk/schools/copyright/). Even if you do not need copyright permission, it is always good practice to acknowledge where your images or text come from. It shows the range of sources you have used.

Make a note of where you found the information and images as well, as you may wish to pursue this stream of thought at a later date. The web is a huge resource for research material to include in your work journal. However, there is so much material on the internet that you could waste a lot of time looking for something that you can use in your work journal. Reema talks about how she conducted her secondary research on textile artist Rachel Howard. Before you go onto the web always be clear about exactly what you are looking for. That way you will be able to find it much faster and you can then use the time you have saved to work on other things. If you are going to include text from a website, do not just copy and paste. You should be using your own words to express your ideas and experiences. Read through the text on the website that you are looking at and make some notes of the most important points. Then you can write these main points in your work journal, in any way you like. Don't forget that if you just copy and paste from a website, you are not selecting the information you really need. On top of that, the examiner who looks at your work journal will want to see your work and notes. Copied text from websites is very easy to spot. You can also find vast collections of images on the web that you can include in your work journal. You can save these images by moving the cursor over the image you are interested in, clicking on the right button of the mouse and then scrolling down the menu to 'Save image as'. If you are using a Mac, then just hold the mouse button down until the menu appears. The images of artworks that you research on the internet cannot be included in your final artworks unless you get permission. There's more about copyright later in this Revision Bite: Secondary Sources: Copyright To find out more about how to search for copyright free images, which you can use in your artwork, visit Bitesize DiDA's Revision Bite: Web Research. If you are photocopying images from a book, cutting out images from a magazine or using an image you have found online, think about whether you need the whole image or just one or more of the details in it. If you only want a few details, then you should crop the picture by cutting out those sections you want to include in your work journal. You can photocopy or print the image out and then cut out the details you want. If it's an online image you could use the cropping tool on any image-editing software, or print it out and then cut it up. For instance, in the photograph above there's a llama on a mountain over-looking Machu Picchu in Peru. You could crop this image to cut out the backdrop so you have the llama only, as shown. Don't fall into the trap of just collecting lots of images to include in your work journal because you can. Before you use any images think about why you need that particular image. Only include an image if there is a good reason for having it. You should also try to make your work journal visually appealing, so you could use scissors with different cutting edges to create a variety of effects, make use of different coloured pens and so on. In this student's work journal Sharmin has used secondary images of models to model the clothes and patterns she has designed. Remember that the images you create (primary) or use (secondary) can be manipulated, overlaid, annotated and built upon. Don't use secondary images too much - it might look as though you are just trying to fill space. There must always be a reason why you have included something in your work journal. When making use of a secondary image don't forget to read the text that goes with the picture because it will certainly contain information that you can include in your work journal. If you are taking images from a newspaper, then read the news item that goes with the picture and make a note of the important points. Artists and writers own the copyright for anything they have created. They are protected by copyright law - this prevents other people from copying it without their permission. Copyright law protects anything you can copy - whether it is images or text from books, magazines or the internet. You are allowed to copy images and text for your own private use as long as you do not plan to use it in your own artwork or make any money from it. If you are including secondary sources in your work journal then that's fine - but do acknowledge where you got them from whereever possible. If you are planning to use somebody else's work in your artwork, then you must get permission from whoever owns the copyright. The copyright details are usually included in books and magazines on the front page. For TV programmes you may need to contact the production company. Websites usually have copyright information at the bottom of the webpage. For example if you look at the bottom of the BBC Schools website there is a link that says Schools Copyright (bbc.co.uk/schools/copyright/). Even if you do not need copyright permission, it is always good practice to acknowledge where your images or text come from. It shows the range of sources you have used.

Assessment objective 2 (AO2) is about analysing (looking carefully) and evaluating (having opinions about) all sorts of images and objects made by other artists and designers. You'll need to think about why designed objects or artworks are so important in our lives. Assessment objective 2 (AO2) follows on from your work on AO1 [AO1: Assessment objective 1 - the part of the GCSE Art and Design course that is about recording observations, experiences and ideas. ] - recording and observing. Remember AO2 should be followed throughout your coursework. The best way to approach AO2 is by using the SEMI approach. This is explained in the next Revision Bite.

The visual and tactile elements are the individual parts that make up a piece of art, craft or design. In this Revision Bite, we will look at the elements of art, craft and design in more detail. By understanding and using the visual and tactile elements both within your visual work and writing, you will be covering assessment objective 2. The visual and tactile elements are line, tone, colour, pattern, texture, shape and form, and harmony and balance. "The essence of drawing is the line exploring space." A line is a point moving in space. A line can vary in width, length, curvature, colour or direction. Take a look at how artists John Piper and Pablo Picasso make use of line in their artwork. Easton, Portland, Dorset: St George Reform, 1964, John Piper John Piper uses simple white lines on a black background to portray a simple town scene. Look at the detailed use of pattern in the foreground to add a sense of depth to the overall image to the left. Click on the images above and below to see a bigger version. (If you have Flash, click Magnify to see the detail - to remove the viewfinder just click Magnify again.) This is a study by Pablo Picasso for his 'Weeping Woman'. He has used simple lines and blocks of primary colours. Note how the eyes have been emphasised with darker, thicker lines. Have a go at creating a continuous line drawing. Place an object in front of you - consider a stem with leaves, a plant or a flower. Next, do a continuous line drawing using a black biro or fine line pen and don't take your pen off the paper. Don't worry about a few extra lines. James's continuous line drawing If you want to add shadow, use heavier pressure and cross hatch. Again, don't take your pen off the paper. The more you look at the object, the better this drawing will turn out. You could try creating a continuous line drawing with your mouse by visiting www.imokta.co.uk/scribbler.asp. You can even send your continuous line drawing to a friend.

Tone is shading, from dark to light. In the drawing on the right, John Piper has used strong tonal shading. She really stands out from the darkness. This is acheived by the contrasts in tones. Note how the artist has made the right side of the head darker than its background, while the left side is lighter than the background. Figure Drawing, 1941, John Piper Note how the artist has used a combination of dark watercolour wash in the background, with heavy black and white marks in the foreground Click on the images to see a bigger version. (If you have Flash, click Magnify to see the detail - to remove the viewfinder just click Magnify again.) In the picture below the artist has painted a group of glaciated rocks. The darker background contrasts with the lighter tones of the rocks. He has added black lines to emphasise the structure and to create a sense of depth and mood. Glaciated Rocks, Nant Ffrancon, 1944, John Piper

Red, blue and yellow are known as primary colours. In theory, all other colours can be mixed from these three colours. The secondary colours are created by mixing two primary colours. THe secondary colours are green, purple and orange. On a colour wheel harmonious colours are side by side. Complementary colours are opposite each other. The complemantary of any primary colour is made by mixing the other two primaries. Warm colours are based on red and include red, yellow and orange. Cool colours are based on blue and include blue, green and indigo. See how the colours on the colour wheel are grouped together below.

Red is often described as a hot, fiery, passionate colour. Blue is often described as cool and cold and spatial. Yellow and blue are sometimes referred to as dynamic and exciting. Browns and greens can be called natural, calm colours. Artists often use certain colours to evoke particular emotions or create a certain type of atmosphere in an artwork. For example the colour red is often used to convey energy, war, danger, anger, passion, desire and love. Think about how colours can be used to help convey an emotion in your artwork. Remember that the use of colour can evoke different emotions to different people - this is often due to cultural differences or personal experiences. Look at the animation below as a starting point that you can build upon. This website from the Walker Center of Art tries to help students understand the nature of art. Take a look at key question 6: 'Does art express emotions?' and try out the activity: schools.walkerart.org/swita/ Now you have learnt about how artists make use of colour to convey emotions in their artwork have a go at the activity below. Use your knowledge of colour theory to describe the mood of each artwork featured. Intent is how artists work their purpose, ideas and intentions. This information can sometimes be found in interviews or museum guides. Try and look into the historical, economical and/or social impacts that the artist may have experienced to see if you can find out more about their intentions. Remember not all artists have an intention when they create their artwork but art will usually have an affect on the people who view it. Below are lists of descriptive words that will help you think about why something was created and how it might affect a person when they see it or use it. Reason - to shock, to be funny, a form of personal expression, to be abstract, to provoke, to find the truth, to celebrate, to influence, cultural, religious, to challenge, to enforce, propaganda Reason - to wear, to use, to shock, to show wealth, to show importance, to use as part of a ritual/celebration, for protection, a form of currency Reason - trend setting, educational, religious, storytelling, create atmosphere, improve safety, ergonomical, increase efficiency, representation, to shock, to confuse, to calm, marketing, advertising

Henry Moore's reasons for creating sculptures of reclining figures included his own interest in classical sculpture, how materials are represented in Renaissance paintings, humanism, the female form and the power of the mother figure. "I decided on a reclining figure that seeks to tell no story at all... people should have to ponder about what it means". Henry Moore In order to completely cover AO2, analysing and evaluating, you should try to find out why an artist created their artwork. When you think about the media of an artwork it can often be described by the materials it is made from. Remember in AO2 you need to provide evidence that you have evaluated and analysed an artwork. There are many methods and types of materials you can create an artwork from. Below are lists of words that you could use to describe the methods and materials when identifying the media. Materials - paint (oil, acrylic, water based), ink, tempera, gold leaf, canvas, cloth, vellum, glass, photos, cardboard, postcards, plastic, wood, metal Methods - coiling, carving, melting, firing, joining, sewing Materials - clay, glass, paper, silver, gold, wood, plastic, gemstones, feathers, silk, cotton, leather, tiles Methods - drawing, montage, illustrating, advertising, marketing, packaging, make up, hairstyles, tailoring Some artists use unconventional materials in their artwork, for example Chris Ofili included elephant dung in his artwork entitled 'She'. Visit the Main Gallery - Patterns to see his work. Other British artists who have used unconventional materials include Tracey Emin and Damien Hirst.

What is the subject matter of the art, craft or design work you are studying? How can it be described? The 'S' of SEMI stands for 'Subject'. Subject is the first element of the SEMI approach. The words you use to describe the subject matter of a piece of art, craft or design work will depend on the individual work. Figures - man, woman, child, groups of people, royalty, religious figures, families, people in love, people at war Scenes - everyday life, worship, at war, working, sleeping, posing, storytelling Animals - moving, static domestic pets, groups Objects - the still life, everyday objects, food and drink, plants, the landscape, personal belongings, religious artefacts, symbols and signs Abstract - colours, shapes, geometric, patterns, suggestive, mood, emotion, dark, light, powerful, subtle Organic shapes - flowers, stems, petals, flowing, curving, interlocking, curved Design - lettering, text, signs and symbols Purpose - clothes, shoes, hats, jewellery, furniture, houses and buildings, bridges, fabric, wallpaper, designs for print, logos, posters Organic shapes - anatomical, flowers, stems, petals, flowing, curving, interlocking, curved Design - lettering, text, blocks, patterns Human experience - memories, stories, myths and legends, religious, everyday Site-specific - environmental, practical, scientific, aesthetic Now that you have looked through the lists of words that help identify the subjects in art, craft and design have a go at this activity. Identify the subject matter for these artworks.

The author Rod Taylor uses six universal themes when discussing works of art. He believes that these themes are broad enough to group together all works of art, craft and design. The SEMI approach will help you get your ideas straight about all kinds of art, craft and design work - it's just what you need for your assessment objective 2 (AO2). The SEMI approach will help you get good marks for AO2. All art, craft and design work can be described using three or four of these headings. Here's an example of how it works. Here is Duncan Grant's painting 'Garden Path in Spring'. Here is a SEMI analysis of the painting. Now you've got the idea, we'll look at each of the headings in detail in the next four Revision Bites. Follow these links, or find the list on the index page.

If you are using oil paint [oil paint: A powdered pigment that is held together with linseed oil. ], you can experiment with thick and thin areas to create textures. You might want a shiny or matt surface. By adding turpentine to the mix, you can make the paint thinner, more transparent and have a more matt finish. By adding oil (such as linseed or poppy oil) you make the paint thinner, more transparent and give it a more glossy finish. Adding wax will give a soft matt finish and make the paint thicker too. Acrylic paint can be mixed with anything water based, such as water, soap, PVA glue and other water based paint. It can be applied thin or thick. You can try mixing in an acrylic medium to make the paint more transparent. This is useful for glazing effects and more subtle colouring. Water colour and gouache paints are both water based, so like acrylic they can be mixed with anything water based. You should experiment with the surface you are painting on. Try wood, paper, card, glass or metal. Create a collage, cut into the surface, or tear the paper and rejoin it in a different way. Surfaces can be changed in a variety of ways, scratched, roughened, made uneven or smoothed. Try using sandpaper to remove some of the paint from previous painting and then paint onto it some more. Try painting onto a wet surface, and a dry surface. Try painting over old painting once it's dry. You can be surprised how good the results can be. Make use of a palette knife to discover new textures, or draw into the paint with the wrong end of your paintbrush. Try adding things such as glue, rice or sand onto, or into, the paint to build up or create a variety of interesting textures. Try different sizes and shapes of brushes. Decorating brushes are a cheap alternative to large artist quality brushes. Try painting without brushes, using pieces of wood or plastic as scrapers, or bits of rag to apply the paint. When you are experimenting have an idea in mind of what you want to achieve, and then see what techniques give you the most success. Research the work of other painters to get some ideas of what you can do. You could also research the medium, so to continue with the previous example you could find out about oil paints. Information about -

You can explore a range of materials on which to draw, such as different thicknesses, types and textures of paper. Experiment to see the difference it makes what type of marks you use to draw the same subject. Try making marks that are all the same all over. Then try to get a wide range of different marks into the same drawing. Use wet and dry mediamedia: a collective name for images, video and audio. Try drawing with wet media like watercolours, ink or watered-down acrylic paint. Try different mark-making materials from pencils to pastels, inks, pens, charcoal, sticks, matches. Try fine aquarelle pencils for subtle colour blending, or make a delicate wash by brushing over them with water. Try using different types of eraser. Try using erasers to make marks and remove parts of the drawing. Putty rubbers are very soft and can be used to lighten shadows, to give delicate shading, by rubbing gently at areas you've already shaded. Try rubbing out an area and then drawing back into the mess that is left behind. Adrian, Helen and Marian explain why they enjoy drawing with different materials.

When creating a collage [collage: A collage is an image that is made up of a mixture of materials, such as newspaper, magazine cuttings, string and so on. ] try to experiment with a variety of materials - paper, string, plastics, bits of wood, plaster, tissues - in fact almost anything. Then try to have fun with the materials you've chosen. You could photocopy photos, official documents, letters, certificates, newspapers, magazines or use the real ones. Consider tearing the papers, layering them, scrunching them up into balls, folding them to create ridges or bending them to create waves. Look at artists such as Robert Rauschenberg (shown here), Henri Matisse, Pablo Picasso, Kurt Schwitters, Eva Hesse, or Jasper Johns for inspiration. Karimah experimented with lots of different media and techniques. See her work in this Revision Bite: Developing ideas. If you are working in 3D, you might use materials you can model, carve or construct. These could be plaster of Paris, modroc (plaster bandage), wire, chicken wire, wood, cardboard, or clay. You need to consider the reason for choosing a particular material, what it might be used for, and how you would use it. You'll also need to think about the finish - will it be glazed or covered with papier-mÃ¢chÃ©? It might be that you are casting from your hand or foot, or you want to create a piece based on the body. Before you make it full size, try out a few experiments. Mix the plaster and pour into a plastic ice cream tub. When it is cool and solid, take it out - it's now ready to carve. Plaster of Paris is relatively soft and so itâ€™s easy to carve with a knife or metal clay tools. You can also use shaping/smoothing tools such as a surform. Experiment with images and plaster of Paris by putting things such as photos or text in the bottom of something shallow. For example, take a plastic glue top/lid, mix the plaster and pour over the photo. When it sets, take the solid plaster out of the lid. Casts can be made by using plaster bandage or by pouring plaster into a mould, or over your hand/foot. Remember that you need to cover your hand with petroleum jelly (vaseline) to stop the plaster sticking to you! You also need to build a wall around the area that is to be cast, to stop the plaster running away. Look at the different ways in which artists such as Rachel Whiteread, George Segal, Rose Garrard, and Henry Moore have used plaster of Paris. See Rachel Whiteread, George Segal and Henry Moore artworks in the Main Gallery - Sculpture.

Still Life, 1914, Pablo Picasso Click on the images below to see a bigger version. (If you have Flash, click Magnify to see the detail - to remove the viewfinder just click Magnify again.) Â© Artist, Photo Courtesy of MuHKA - Belgium Self Portrait, 1982, Tony Cragg In his 'Self Portrait' piece (shown here) you can see he has used bits of plastic including a spatula, a flip flop and felt tips pens. Try collecting different materials and experiment with them in different ways to see what you can do. For example, try organising them by texture, shape, colour or symbolism. Find out more about Shape and Form in the Revision Bite: Visual and tactile elements.

Hew Locke uses materials like thick card and coloured plastics to construct his pieces. He cuts, twists, tears and sticks the pieces together to construct sculptures or hangings. Laura Ford starts with a metal armature [armature: A framework used to give a rigid support to a sculpture. It is often made from metal or wire and can be padded with paper or wood. ]. She talks us through her creative process. Tom Hill uses his initial sketches to create objects such as chickens, fish and birds in wire.

Chicken wire or wire mesh can be used to shape and form. It can be shaped over a tailor's dummy, for example, to make a body or torso structure. This can then be covered with papier mÃ¢chÃ©, fabrics, or plaster. Experiment with small pieces of wire mesh, then cover it with photocopies, fabrics, papier mÃ¢chÃ© or any other material you fancy using. Watch these video clips showing how Jenni Dutton makes dresses using chicken wire and decorates shoes with various materials like broken glass. Jenni talks about the creative process involved in making dresses. In this clip she showcases 'Holly Dress' and 'Hair Dress'. In this clip Jenni talks about the 'Mackerel Corset' and why she chose to use mackerel skins. Apart from dresses and corsets, Jenni also creates shoes. Here she talks about the 'Queen of Sheba's Shoe'. Watch more video clips in Artists explanations and SEMI Gallery - Video clips.

You can decorate by drawing into or onto the surface with tools such as needles or knives. Textures can be made by pressing the clay onto a textured surface such as a rubber car mat or a brick wall. Consider the colour and final look of the piece. You might want to paint areas or make patterns with coloured slips. Experiment with glaze/colour tests before deciding what to put onto your work. Remember that you can spoil a beautiful piece of work with the wrong type of glaze. The colour, whether matt or shiny, needs to be planned and well thought out. Kate Malone uses very particular glazes for her work. She has spent years developing her knowledge and understanding. Look at the Revision Bite: Developing ideas to see how our student Shreya has used layers of pattern and colour on her Mehendi [Mehendi: A temporary henna tattoo artistically and skillfully applied onto the body. Traditionally this is applied onto hands, forearms, lower legs and feet. ] hand piece. She painted each layer separately and fired it more than six times. Remember glazes are a form of liquid glass. They can be mixed with water from dry ingredients or they might come in liquid form and be stored in small containers. The finished effect from using a glaze can be transparent, opaque, shiny or matt. Glazes can enhance your work or ruin it. So it is really important that you try to learn how to use them to their best advantage. This takes trial and error and some research. Ask your teacher for guidance. Keep notes of your experiments, so that if you have a good or interesting result you can re-use it.

In this Revision Bite you'll find some more ideas and examples to help you experiment with media, and to write up your results for AO3. The reason you need to experiment with media is to see what's most suitable for your ideas - and you won't know until you've tried it! Karman experimented with a variety of media. Her experiments with print led to her drawings/sketches, where she planned her thoughts and compositional arrangements. She made a few textile samples to test her ideas and the colours that she might use before she made her final pieces. See Karman's experimentation in her work journal. Lindsay was having difficulties with his theme. It wasn't until he changed the materials and techniques that he was using and began to paint, that his work began to go in a direction that interested him, stimulated new ideas and resulted in a good standard of work. Lindsay's background notes and sketches Tom Hill, a wire sculptor, talks about the stages of his idea development, from drawing to sculpting. Grayson Perry, ceramicist, talks about how he draws ideas from emotional events to incorporate into the themes for his vases. Faisal Abdu'allah talks us through his appreciation for Renaissance paintings and how he uses this inspiration to create works like 'Madonna and Child' as shown here. Jenni Dutton, textile artist, talks about how myths and legends inspire her. She also explains how initially she was interested in forms of wrapping before moving on to creating dresses out of unusual materials.

Looking at other artists can help you to develop your ideas and experiments. Take a look at the Main Gallery to see works by Chris Ofili, Rebecca Horn and Tony Cragg. She started work by studying things from the sea from first-hand experience. She looked at shells, coral, fish, sea creatures, seaweed etc, and used water colours, pen and pencil. My art exhibition shows a series of artwork that I have created which all deal with my journey from Nigeria to England. During the term, I have created a series of art pieces that concentrate on the theme of 'Identity'. In the art pieces, I explore the journey that I have made from Nigeria to live in England. The reason that I have focused on this subject under the title of 'Identity' is because, the journey I have made was a life changing journey and it is a significant part of my identity. I first started exploring this journey by creating self portraits, this was to develop my skills and ideas in art to help me to become more advanced. I then planned and created a collage of Africa. This collage shows the journey that I made to England from Nigeria, through symbols, colours and pictures used to represent the contrasting countries. The main elements that I included in my collage work is that England has a cool calm atmosphere and climate whilst Nigeria is hot and roars with excitement and noise. Nigeria has a beautiful collection of exotic animals that run wild and free, whilst in England the animals are locked up in a zoo. The environment in England is clean and fresh but in Nigeria, it is dirty and humid. I chose to show my journey this way because it is an effective way of showing the striking difference between England and Nigeria. After the first collage I realised that collage is my strongest point in art and I began to produce a series of mixed media pieces that featured collage. 'Tree of Life' is a piece where I used a symbol of a tree to represent my life growing out of a symbol of Africa. In 'The first self portrait collage' I used maps to show the physical part of my journey. 'The second self portrait collage', is a piece where I used the different flags of England and Nigeria to show my journey and the comparison between England and Nigeria. I have linked my theme of 'Identity', with numerous artists because they have all been exploring a similar theme to me. Gerard Quenum is an African artist who uses dolls to symbolise identity, Richard Long, an artist who expresses his journeys through photographs, Louise Bourgeois who deals with her identity by using memories of her childhood, Frida Khalo a Mexican artist who uses powerful images to show her identity and Henri Matisse who uses his knowledge of African art and refines it into a simpler form in his pieces of art. I have been to the National Gallery, the Tate Modern, the October Gallery, the Century City exhibition and the library to learn about artists that may have connections with my theme. I have been exploring my cultural and family background through family photographs. This is because the photographs prompt ideas for units of work and they tell different stories through the atmosphere or pose in the picture. The journey in the art pieces is presented in mixed styles of aboriginal art and African art. I do this to experiment with the different ways of presenting my journey to viewers and to give a variation in the techniques and arts styles that I use. My progress whilst creating units of artwork has improved dramatically compared to the beginning of term where I was unable to develop and explore ideas. Overall, I am pleased with the way that I have managed to link all my units of artwork together all under the topic of 'Identity'. I have improved my art skills from the beginning of the term, when I had very little art skills. I am glad that I can now expand and explore ideas, compared to when I first started art and I could not develop an idea because of lack of experience and knowledge of art.

The more you experiment, the more your work will stand out. Take risks with the media you are using, to really show off your creativity. As you experiment, you'll find you have more success, and the more your confidence will grow. You can then start to break the rules or make up your own rules. Try using materials in unusual ways and combining different papers and cards with pencils, chalk, inks or paint. You can also use things such as sponges, straws or various types of brushes to get different effects with paint. For example this picture below was created by drawing onto sandpaper with wax crayon and then ironing this onto a clean sheet of cartridge paper to create an impressionist effect. These effects were created using ink and tea streaked onto paper. Experiment with other unusual materials and try layering them on top of one another.

Creating a mixed media artwork involves overlaying materials, colours or tones. They can be both 2D and 3D. Take a look at Picasso's work below. He has used painted wood and upholstery fringe. Click on the image to see a bigger version. (If you have Flash, click Magnify to see the detail - to remove the viewfinder just click Magnify again.) Still Life, 1914, Pablo Picasso Other great artists, such as Leonardo da Vinci, Gustav Klimt, Edgar Degas and George Braque, also used mixed media techniques. Can you find out what materials they used? For example, here's some information about how Leonardo Da Vinci experimented with new materials for his fresco 'The Last Supper': http://arthistory.about.com/cs/leonardo/a/last_supper.htm

Hew Locke is a mixed media artist. The materials he makes use of are brightly coloured and glittery - toothpics, sequins, feather boas and so on. You can find out more about Hew Lock here: http://www.hewlocke.net Barr Lewis is a Canadian artist who creates mixed media artworks. Her site: www.colorandpassion.com includes information about the materials she uses. The artist has also included an art project page which details how you can create a mixed media miniature figurative relief: www.syzygyartgallery.com

Have a look at work by different photographers who use different styles and subject matters. Look at those who have worked in different historic times, or in unusual places. Developing on from this idea, you could study photo journalists, and work out how they might structure a story. Martin Parr talks about why he enjoys photography, and takes us through his creative process. Take a look at some of the artists we have featured in our Main Gallery - Photography page. Find out more about Martin Parr in the Artist Explanations and SEMI Gallery.

AO3 is all about experimenting - but you can't start on that until you've found a theme that inspires you. This Revision Bite should help you find subjects you can really go to town on. You can get lots of ideas by making a spidergram, mindmap or flowchart. Don't stop until there's nothing left to write, however strange the connections you make! Write the theme your teacher has given you in the middle of a piece of paper. Then just see what that theme makes you think about. Whatever it is, write it down, and then see what that makes you think about next. Just let each idea connect in some way with the next. Let your ideas flow. Don't worry that they might seem silly. Have a look at Shreya and Kathy's spidergrams below for examples of the start of a spidergram - click on them to see a bigger version. (If you have Flash, click Magnify to see the detail - to remove the viewfinder just click Magnify again.) Ideas need to be developed and refined. Making notes about how you've changed and improved your ideas can help both you and the examiner understand your work. Watch the video clips featuring Fiona Rae and Paula Rego as they talk about this below. Paula Rego talks about her decisions on who will become the focus in the painting she is creating. The way your work looks is very important for your final grade. You'll need to explain the ideas you've had while exploring a particular theme. Can you show how these have inspired you, as you've worked towards your final piece? Remember, whether you choose a work journal [work journal: A book in which a daily record of things that have happened is kept. An alternative name for a sketchbook or log book. If you divide your preparation work up, it will be easier to make sure you're doing everything you need to do. For example you could use one display board, or three or four pages of a sketchbook, for each assessment objective. Don't forget you'll need to do this for each piece of work you submit. If you're using work journals, we'd suggest that you have one for each piece of coursework.

Think about how you show others your work. These layout tips can be used in your displays as well as your work journals. Space your work out evenly and don't be afraid to leave some white space. Make use of imaginary vertical and horizontals lines to make the layout look tidy. You can overlay images if you want, but be careful not to let your work become too cluttered. Sample layout using a "washing line" Use the "washing line" idea. Hang your work from an imaginary horizontal line. This also works with a strong vertical line. Sample layout with a "horizon" Create a "horizon" in the display . Make sure that all your work goes above and below the imaginary horizontal line. This will also works with a vertical line. Don't display your work at angles without being sure that's right. It usually isn't. It can make your work look untidy and doesn't help the viewer when they are trying to see your work development.

As part of each project, you have to describe your art or design work. This is where you explain your ideas, and show you've done all your coursework. it needs to be clear that you kept assessing what you were doing while you were doing it, to show how your ideas moved along. Make rough notes when you do work of any kind. You need to show evidence of what you have learned. It's easier to record things while you are working than at the end of your project. Here are some questions to help you with your written comments - plus some phrases you could use for your answers. Explain how your theme has changed or developed. What new ideas have you had? Helen's theme is 'Overhead and Underneath'. She talks about how she experimented with different techniques before choosing one to use in her final piece.

Use words such as inspired, interested, fascinated, provoked, shocked, disturbed, discovered and explored, to show that the artist's or craftsperson's work has really helped you to create your own artwork. These kinds of words are good because they sound personal and express what you mean. Page about Frida Kahlo from a student's work journal This student writes about how she was disturbed by Frida Kahlo's "scary" self portraits. Frida Kahlo had to go through a lot surgery after a pole pierced through her body in a bus accident. The student has seen photos of Frida Kahlo, and thinks she was pretty but must have thought of herself as ugly after the accident. After studying these portraits in detail, the student had re-occuring dreams, which influenced the work she later created. For example, if you make a comment about an artist's use of colour, have a go at mixing those colours in paint yourself and stick them alongside your written comment. These colours might then be used later on in your own work. This student has drawn the throat of sheep in an aboriginal style. Using earthy colours and lines he explains how this result reminds him of "a zebra because of its striping pattern".

Don't just look at the obvious. Broaden your research to include craftworkers, designers, contemporary art and art forms from across the world. The artwork that you look at can come from a wide range of sources. For example, looking at your next-door neighbour's paintings is just as valid as looking at the work of a famous artist from the Tate Modern gallery in London. What's important is what you learn and how an artist helps you to develop your ideas and make connections. Take a look at the Artist Explanations and SEMI Gallery, the BBC's Art website, bbc.co.uk/arts, for more information or try an online search. It's very important to look at other artists' work to get ideas, but you must not copy their artwork and use it as your own final piece. You need to show evidence that looking at artists' work has helped you to develop your ideas and inspired you in some way to create your final piece of work.

You might choose to use a colour range inspired by an artist's use of colour in a painting or sculpture. You may choose to create a painting using the same brush strokes as your chosen artist. You could show your study skills by experimenting with different art periods as shown in the activity above. Your choice may reflect an artist's composition. For example, a magnified view, an oddly shaped paper or a similarly structured sculpture. An artist may specialise in a particular subject. For example, natural forms, mechanical forms, the body, portraiture, fruit, flowers, animals, landscape or still life. You may also choose to specialise. Try to identify what the artist you have been inspired is passionate about. Here are some ideas: recycling, women's issues, emotions, scale, using found objects, the banality of everyday life, violence, unusual lighting or viewpoints and so on. For example, you might choose to do a still life with similar objects used by the artist you are inspired by. A theme that creates the opposite effect to that of your artist.

You have to show what you can achieve within the 10 hour exam. This needs to be work done from scratch and completed under exam conditions - starting with a blank sheet of paper, blank canvas, lump of clay, etc. Think about what media you can prepare before the day of the exam. You should do as much as possible to make those 10 hours run as smoothly as possible. If you are going to use any unusual materials, check in advance that they can be brought in for you, otherwise you'll need to bring them in yourself. Also double check that there'll be enough equipment to go around. For more preparation tips read Revision Bite: The final exam - Preparing for the timed test

Once you know your theme for any unit of coursework or for your final exam, you need to think about the four assessment objectives (AO1, AO2, AO3 and AO4). As you follow the assessment objectives, you'll be brainstorming, researching and experimenting with ideas (AO1, AO2, AO3). You'll be recording all this in your work journal, and preparing to make your final art work or object for AO4. In each unit you do for GCSE Art and Design, you need to combine the four 'assessment objectives' together to form one large volume of work. Here's how to approach them. Start with some ideas about your theme. Choose your theme and group as many ideas about it as you can - perhaps in a spidergram. Try bouncing ideas off your friends or looking up word associations in a thesaurus or subject associations in an encyclopedia. These ideas will help you with the next stage. For fuller details, see the main Assessment Objectives units.

For your GCSE Art and Design coursework you can follow the 'endorsed' or 'unendorsed' course. They're both marked in the same way. If you're doing a full GCSE in Art and Design, whether endorsed or unendorsed, you'll do two, three or four units of coursework - it will depend on the exam board. Your teacher will decide the unit topics - they could be something like 'Natural forms', or 'Me, myself'. Your 'controlled test', or final exam, comes at the end of the course. It takes ten hours, and you'll do it over two or more days. You get between four and eight weeks to prepare for this, depending on your exam board. This is a broad-based course, so you work in two or more areas of study. You need to produce coursework that covers at least two of the areas of study listed below. This is a specialised course, so you work in only one area of study for the whole course. You need to produce coursework that covers just one area listed below. If you choose to do two endorsements, you'll get two GCSEs!

Coursework + final exam = GCSE! Remember to find out which examination board you're following - your teacher will tell you. The number of coursework units you need to do, and the amount of time you get to prepare in before your final exam, depends on your board. Coursework can give you up to 60 per cent of your marks. A coursework unit should include all the work you did while preparing your final piece or pieces. The controlled test can give you 40 per cent of your marks. You will need to respond to one starting point, or title.

The coursework you do in the build-up towards the final exam is very important - it can count for 60 per cent of your GCSE mark! So remember to label your coursework carefully, and to keep it safe. Coursework is made up from all the work you do in your two-year GCSE course. It will include your work journals, sketchbooks, or log books, plus your supporting studies, developmental pieces, written notes and final pieces of work. It does not include the final exam. Remember coursework is worth 60 per cent of your final overall GCSE mark, and the final exam is worth 40 per cent. If you don't know which exam board you're following - ask your teacher. Your teacher will give you the starting point or title for each unit of coursework you're doing. Each unit is made up of a body of work that must cover and link all four assessment objectives together. Here's a reminder of what they are. AO1 - Record and observe AO2 - Analyse and evaluate AO3 - Develop and explore your ideas AO4 - Personal response

Everything you do in art is assessed. At the end of the course you may want to leave out some of your work, but only do this if your teacher agrees - it might be more useful than you think. Even unfinished or unsuccessful pieces can be very useful to show that you tried something. Failed experiments are good evidence of your research. So don't throw away any work, however embarrassing you think it is, before asking your teacher's advice. Remember your coursework mark is made up of the sum of all your units of work, and is worth 60 per cent of your final GCSE grade. Anyone who has never made a mistake has never tried anything new. Half of art is accident, but there is no accident without free experiment. The best place to store all your artwork is probably in your art drawer at school, or you could put it in a large folder to keep it safe. If you think you might do a higher course in art and design, then an A1 portfolio would be worth buying. Keep three-dimensional work on a high shelf or in a storeroom. If in doubt, ask your art teacher. You need to be extra careful with ceramic work, because this is very fragile. Make sure you always take photographs of your ceramic work before and after it's put in the kiln. Write your name on the back of your work. Everything - written notes, your work journals, little pieces of paper and photographs - should be neatly and clearly labelled. Three-dimensional work also needs careful labelling. Put small stickers on the underside, or carefully write your name in pencil.

The work you do as you prepare to make your art, craft or design object needs to be recorded in a work journal, log or sketchbook. This work is called your preparation studies. It's more important than your final pieces, because it shows the examiners that all the assessment objectives have been met. This Revision Bite will help you get it right. Whatever you call it (we've called it a work journal), preparation studies are worth around 75 per cent of your overall GCSE mark. Your preparation work for the assessment objectives is more important than your final piece. So do look at Assessment objectives in your course. Preparation studies support each of your units of work, and should show that all the assessment objectives have been met. The size of your work journal is up to you and your art teacher. You could have several work journals if you wanted. In some schools you do all the preparation work on large sheets of paper, and bind them together at the end.

Use bits of coloured paper, write notes to describe what you're doing, or add a title to explain the images. Each exam board calls the final exam a different name - terminal exam, external examination or controlled test. The exam is worth 40 per cent of your GCSE mark. Make sure you know which exam board you're following, so you know what the chosen theme is, and how many weeks you've got to prepare in. The final exam is a ten-hour exam, and it's worth 40 per cent of your total GCSE marks. You'll have between four and eight weeks preparation time before it - depending on your exam board. If you don't know which exam board you're following - ask your teacher! You must respond to one starting point - your exam board sets the exam titles. You choose one starting point in your chosen option - there are separate papers for each option. Now is not the time to try something new. If you've never done ceramics before - then don't do it now! Remember this is the final exam, a chance to gain 40 per cent of your overall GCSE marks. Be confident and ambitious - but stick with what you've done in your preparation studies.

Kate's brainstorm. Once you know your theme, get going with your preparation studies - as you do this, make sure you cover all four assessment objectives. All this should be done in the weeks before you make your final examination piece. Once it's finished, you'll show final outcome(s) and connect your work to the work of others. Remember - you'll have ten hours to create your final examination piece. Visit Your coursework and final exam to see how many preparation weeks your exam board gives you.

Alan Davie is a prominent Scottish artist well known for his work in a range of mediums including drawing, painting, and screenprinting. He was born in 1920 and graduated from the Edinburgh Royal College of Art in 1940. After serving in World War II he began teaching in Edinburgh and in 1947 became a professional jazz musician. In 1948 he took up a travelling art scholarship from the college and travelled throughout Europe in 1948-9. In Venice he met Peggy Guggenheim, an influential art collector, who introduced him to American abstract expressionism. Whilst exhibiting in New York in 1956 he befriended other artists including Jackson Pollock, Willem De Kooning and Mark Rothko. His work continues to be widely exhibited across the USA and Europe. Much of Alan's work is colourful, vibrant, on a large scale and reflects the artist's love of jazz music, non-western cultural symbols, ancient religious and ethnic influences. My ideas are intuitive and most ideas come from my thoughts. The art I create is no way expressive or impressionist, it just comes from an artist drive I have to keep on creating. The work of art seems to be something thrown off, a by-product of the process of being and working. Art just happens, like falling in love. When I am working, I am aware of a striving, a yearning, the making of many impossible attempts at a kind of transmutation â€“ a searching for a formula for the magical conjuring of the unknowable. Many times the end seems just within reach, only to fly to pieces before me as I reach for it. I paint because I have nothing, or I paint because I am full of ideas ... or I paint because after I last painted, something appeared miraculously out of it. The titles are not necessarily directly linked to the image, they are more often terms I have to use to catalogue the artwork I have created. Inside is a place of magic; resounding, surrounding, where big hanging works in progress are constantly being transformed and re-worked, making a shifting environment of developing moods, spaces, colours, forms, poetry fragments, script, signs and symbols, laughing, singing.

Backa Carin was born in 1973 in Uppsala, Sweden. She graduated from Stockholm University College of Arts, Craft and Design in 2000 with a master's degree in fine art and has since worked as a professional artist. Her works have been exhibited internationally and in main galleries in Sweden. She creates installation pieces in porcelain and stoneware that often blur dreams and reality. The symbolic signs of dreams are astonishingly general. A lot of people recognise their own dreams when they see my work. She views her role as an artist as being similar to that of a set designer in that she engages the viewer to enter the artwork and become part of it. The installations are often on a large scale and incorporate movement, noise and light. My desire is to give the viewer an impression of life; the encounter between what is beautiful and horrible, the beauty and destructiveness of love, and the fact that we are immortal until we die. When I was about to start working on my Master of Fine Art project I had an intense dream. In this dream I was looking at the exhibition of all the MFA students' art projects. The artwork that was most interesting was a long corridor covered with tentacles. The impression of walking through it was pleasant and at the same time disgusting as the tentacles reached out almost touching your body. When I woke up I realized that the corridor should become my MFA artwork. The feeling of it, the size, material colour and expression was so real and clear in the dream all that was left for me to do was to make it. When creating the corridor artwork I tried to stay as close to the dream as possible. So the shape of the tiles had to be organic and skin like. The corridor bent round in my dream so I built walls to reflect this, the corridor had to be the same scale and shape as what I had seen in my dream. Since the material of the tentacles was porcelain in the dream I made several moulds of plaster and then poured porcelain clay in to them. I made around 400 tentacle tiles to create this installation. The greatest source of inspiration for me is just to keep working. One project leads to another like a chain of happenings. One artwork inspires me to a new one. My two children give me inspiration in the way that they help me see the building stones in life and how people develop from the very beginning. To see a little person explore life is very interesting and you learn a lot about yourself and humanity. Other sources of inspiration are my friends around me and the long discussions about everything. Love and death are also really important. Other artists that have influenced me in no particular order include Eva Hesse, Louise Borgouise, Gerhard Richter, Matthew Barney, Damien Hirst, Paul McCarthy, Mona Hatoum, among others. For me it is really simple: I can't do anything else. If I could do something else I would choose that. I think that to be an artist, living off what you create, you have to be a special kind of a person. It is not enough that you are talented. You have to be really intense in the creating process. The wish to create has to be stronger than all other wishes.

Born in 1950, Caroline graduated from the Leicester School of Art in 1969 and the Central School of Art and Design, London in 1972. Although Caroline trained as a jeweller she soon diversified into textiles and sculptural installations incorporating clothing as pieces of art which are not intended to be worn. Caroline uses garments to explore ideas about personal identity and the portrayal of hidden feelings and emotions. Her recent work concentrates not only on clothing and textiles but on the space around garments on the body and shadows. She has been exhibited widely throughout the world. Caroline was the winner of the Jerwood Prize for Applied Arts: Textiles in 1997. 'Dress with Holes' is part of a body of work I made using shadows as an integral part. Previous work had used the dress as a metaphor for a person, but with these works, I was using the play between object and image to refer to substantial and insubstantial elements. Shadows of people are both part of them and separate, perhaps the outermost visual boundary of someone, giving a likeness but more usually a distortion. There are many stories, like Peter Schlemihl or Peter Pan, about people trading their shadows with the devil or otherwise becoming separated and the subsequent struggle to reunite with it. My intention was to give the shadow equal attention to the dress. The silk of the dress was dyed a mid grey and was a lightweight, transparent fabric. Because the silk was so fine the shadow carried the details of overlaps, seams, creases. In the shadow, I painted the inside spaces of the dress on the wall behind, like the neck, cuffs and the hem, so it looks like there might be a lining to the shadow, give a sense of three-dimensions. I was also interested in the process of completing a work in the space it would be exhibited. These pieces depend on the theatrical nature of traditional art galleries - smooth white walls, controlled lighting. I always started with the light source and worked by placing the dress to get the right shadow.

Kate has been a ceramicist for over 30 years. She remains fascinated with the creative process and likens the way clay can be transformed to a spirited, colourful and glazed vessel through firing to the growth of a tree from a seed. Her passion for ceramics was strengthened at high school, and experimentation with other art mediums strengthened her conviction that pottery was her natural vocation. The work Kate creates ranges in size from intricate palm-sized pieces to exuberant, bold pots large enough for children to sit in. She also creates a variety of work from public fountains to gallery installation pieces. Kate has become well known for her use of distinctive crystalline glazes on her work. The crystalline glazes produce crystal growth on the surface (as seen on 'Queen Pineapple'). The glazes can almost be bad taste as they are so glitzy and clever, like 80s disco wallpaper or jazzy wrapping paper. I myself enjoy kitsch and aim to sometimes offset crystal bad taste with kitsch â€“ thus marrying form and surface. At other times crystals can be gentle and extraordinarily delicate making them a fabulously versatile friend to have in the often difficult glaze department. Key influences on Kate's work are the natural world, fertility and the magic of growth, which she refers to as the "life force". Positive symbolism, fun and humour are also key to her work. Although most of Kate's pieces are based on natural forms, such as fruit and vegetables, she cites fashion designers Zandra Rhodes and Jean Muir as inspirations for the way she "dresses up" her pots. I prepare my clay very soft. I use T Material which usually arrives pretty hard, so I slice up a bag, make rows of wells in each slice, fill those with water, wait a few days and then wedge. I roll coils using both hands. I concentrate by closing my eyes and feeling the coil and reacting to it through touch alone. When I meet students who admit to not being able to roll a prefect coil I tell them to do it blindfold and get good reports back. You can not really see anything below your hands so you do really have to rely on touch alone to roll a coil. I adore rolling perfect soft long coils. I mix [glaze] very thick. I apply using a variety of brushes. I try to create forms that will work with the fluidity of the glaze, create pools for crystals to grow in, and shoulders and round rims and gulleys and valleys for them to slide off and show their trail of movement. I often use three to six different glazes on one surface and blob and layer them together in a series of patches. These overlap in areas and create other effects. I keep a record of the order in which I apply the different recipes as effects change if the order changes.

Queen Pineapple, 1995 Click 'Next' for some background information on this artist. Kate has been a ceramicist for over 30 years. She remains fascinated with the creative process and likens the way clay can be transformed to a spirited, colourful and glazed vessel through firing to the growth of a tree from a seed. Her passion for ceramics was strengthened at high school, and experimentation with other art mediums strengthened her conviction that pottery was her natural vocation. The work Kate creates ranges in size from intricate palm-sized pieces to exuberant, bold pots large enough for children to sit in. She also creates a variety of work from public fountains to gallery installation pieces. Kate has become well known for her use of distinctive crystalline glazes on her work. The crystalline glazes produce crystal growth on the surface (as seen on 'Queen Pineapple'). The glazes can almost be bad taste as they are so glitzy and clever, like 80s disco wallpaper or jazzy wrapping paper. I myself enjoy kitsch and aim to sometimes offset crystal bad taste with kitsch â€“ thus marrying form and surface. At other times crystals can be gentle and extraordinarily delicate making them a fabulously versatile friend to have in the often difficult glaze department. Key influences on Kate's work are the natural world, fertility and the magic of growth, which she refers to as the "life force". Positive symbolism, fun and humour are also key to her work. Maxine explains why she enjoys creating textile art and how her approach is different from other contemporary artists. Maxine Bristow is a textile artist. Born and educated in Lancashire, she studied textiles at Manchester Metropolitan University and now teaches at the University of Chester. Maxine's work is intricate, rooted in traditional needlecraft and demonstrates a high level of expertise. Much of her work is minimalist and on first glance the pieces evoke images of warmth and homeliness but on closer inspection the repetitiveness of the needlework becomes suffocating. Creativity is often seen as being intuitive and expressive, it's adventurous, it's exciting. The way I work is very laborious, very boring. Art doesn't have to be splashing paint around. There can be a lot of meaning, emotion and expression through things that are very ordered. You can express a lot through things that are quiet, are very still and are well made and thought through. 'Through the Surface': a collaborative project between textile artists in Britain and Japan. www.throughthesurface.com

'Holly Dress' and 'Human Hair Dress'. 'Empty Dress' and 'Mackerel Corset'. 'Queen of Sheba's Shoes'. Jenni is a conceptual clothing artist who trained at St Martin's and the Byam Shaw School of Art in London. Using clothing, Jenni constructs pieces around body forms which can then be torn, burnt or bleached and then rebuilt. Jenni used to use to create suspended human figures made from wire and paper, but became more interested in the actual wrapping and so moved on to creating dresses and shoes. The reason I chose dresses is because it's such a strong symbol for women. The most unusual material Jenni has used for her art is mackerel skins, with these she created a mackerel skin corset. In the video clips below Jenni talks about the creation of the 'Holly Dress', 'Human Hair Dress', 'Empty Dress', 'Mackerel Corset' and the 'Queen of Sheba's Shoe'.

Laura Ford talks about the creation of the 'Chintz Girls' and how she wanted to create movement in the pieces. "For 'Head Thinkers' I made lots of drawings. I don't often draw out ideas as trying to make something from a drawing can be very frustrating." Laura studied at the Bath School of Art and the Chelsea School of Art. She is well known for her surreal sculptures and prints. Laura Ford's work makes use of fantastical creatures, they are familiar and endearing: "something you would want to cuddle." The surrealist movement has influenced my work. When normal things transmute in a very dreamlike way they become something else.

Tom Hill talks about the stages of his idea development, from drawing to sculpting. Born in 1971 in Essex, Tom studied jewellery at Middlesex University. In Tom's work he uses steel wire to create 3-d sketches of wildlife, using steel wire in the same way as pen markings. Tom recreates the natural movement of wildlife in his pieces through reliance on carefully observed sketches. My interest in animals stems from me growing up in East Anglia. Drawing is important for all artists really or certainly should be. It's just the best way of processing visual information. Form is described by line, and so with drawing you're immediately looking at an object and transcribing it as a line on a page. I do view what I do as a kind of job. It's not a self indulgent thing of just sitting here and being really creative. You have to view it as a job, but on the other hand it's a really good job.

After sketching ideas into a book Rachel photocopies the ones she likes best, reorganises the elements and then photocopies the final composition onto acetate ready to be sewn onto fabric. Rachel Howard studied embroidery at the Royal College of Art and produces screen prints, embroidered wall hangings, and interior and fashion accessories. She draws inspiration from the ritual events of everyday life such as cooking, eating and household chores. Most of my fabrics I collect from charity shops because I can fill a whole bin bag full of stuff and it'll be very cheap. Also at these places I can often find quite horrific fabrics which I quite like. You can find unusual prints. The machine stitch is another way to create liveliness and texture. I use the sewing machine a bit like a pen. I select the different coloured threads and machine round the figure. I think of myself as a crafts person, a designer and an artist. I think I've got all three in my work. The artist is the drawing, the designer is the composition and the craftsperson is the making of it.

Justin Mortimer talks about what he thinks is a good portrait and why he enjoys using paints. He also talks about how he developed his portrait painting style. Here Justin paints a portrait of TV presenter Mik Scarlet. He talks about how he has interpreted the presenter's personality and put it onto the canvas. Justin is an acclaimed portrait painter. He was born in 1970 and studied at the Slade School of Art in London. He was the winner of BP Portrait Award and his subjects include HM The Queen and David Bowie. I think a really good portrait is a picture that reveals something about the person that is being painted, which not everybody knows, which even the person you're painting might not know. You'll have to express your own feelings about the sitter.

Susie MacMurray is a sculptor and installation artist. Her work makes use of diverse and unusual materials such as human hair, balloons, bird feathers and latex gloves. After a successful career as an orchestral musician, Susie graduated from Manchester Metropolitan University with a BA in sculpture in 2000 and an MA in Fine Art in 2001. Her work has been widely exhibited internationally. She combines university teaching and educational work at Manchester Art Galleries with time in her studio. Recent awards include the Abbey Harris Mural Fund Award in 2006 and the Research and Development Award from The Arts Council England in 2004. 'The Coil' was made in parallel with 'Maidenhair' which is human hair, french knitted in the same way. I was exploring scale and the extreme physical limits of my own body's ability to make work using an identical process. At one end of the scale [for 'The Coil'], I was using the thickest rope I could source. Scaffolding a giant wheel with pegs in it and having to go to the gym to build up enough upper body strength for the coil pieces. For 'Maidenhair', I was french-knitting in the same way but using a tiny bobbin, the smallest crochet hook and working so finely that I could hardly see what I was doing.

To understand a work of art or a beautiful object, you need to think about how the artist or the designer made it. This Revision Bite describes how some of the world's greatest artists and designers set about their work. Do you ever wonder about what an artist wants to say with his/her work? It often depends on how they approach it. Sometimes they'll work directly with their subject, at other times they'll jot down their ideas, or make sketches, before getting started. This preparation work is called a study. Da Vinci used a sketchbook [sketchbook: Evidence of the working process, the preparatory studies, the ideas and thinking behind them. Can be a book, loose pages, or information gathered in a box. ] to record his ideas. They contained detailed anatomical [anatomical: The structure of living things such as plants, people, animals. ] pictures of the human body. He based them on what he found when he dissected human and animal bodies, to help him understand how muscles and bones formed their shape. He also went to the country to study plants and the landscape [landscape: An expanse of natural scenery, trees, hills, lakes etc. ]. Some of his most famous works are based on the careful, delicate studies he drew in his sketchbooks. Click on the images below to see bigger versions of two of Leonardo's studies. (If you have Flash, click Magnify to see the detail - to remove the viewfinder just click Magnify again.) Anatomical Studies, 1500-07, Leonardo Da Vinci The Battle of Anghiari after Leonardo da Vinci, Peter Paul Rubens Leonardo's original 'Battle of Anghiari' cannot be found, but the picture above is a copy made by Rubens, based on the original. See the next pages for the work of William Morris, Pablo Picasso, and video clips of other artists and designers.
