Collecting information is an important part of your project. You will need to collect factsfacts: something that is accurate and true, statistics [statistics: collection and interpretation of data ] and images from various sources. In this section, you will find out about different types of information you will need for your project and where to find them. Secondary sources of information: newspaper If you use information that has been produced by somebody else, it is known as a secondary source. It's important to keep records showing where all the information from secondary sourcessecondary sources: a commentary or analysis of information that has been produced by someone else that you used came from. For notes on the correct way to acknowledge sources, see the Bitesize DiDA: Bibliography section.

Collecting information is an important part of your project. You will need to collect factsfacts: something that is accurate and true, statistics [statistics: collection and interpretation of data ] and images from various sources. In this section, you will find out about different types of information you will need for your project and where to find them. Secondary sources of information: newspaper If you use information that has been produced by somebody else, it is known as a secondary source. It's important to keep records showing where all the information from secondary sourcessecondary sources: a commentary or analysis of information that has been produced by someone else that you used came from. For notes on the correct way to acknowledge sources, see the Bitesize DiDA: Bibliography section. When using secondary sources you need to be aware that the information could be biased. Information is biased when it is written to give only one particular opinion or to influence people's views. Could this report be slightly biased? You need to avoid using biased information. Sometimes you won't be able to find the information you require from secondary sources and you may have to create information yourself. Any information that you create yourself is known as a primary source. You will need to show some evidence of using primary sources in your project work.

For the D201 project, you are likely to have to produce two of the three types of screen-based publications - websites, information points and presentations. You will probably be familiar with websites and presentations, but you might have to do a bit more investigation to find examples of information points. Spend a bit of time investigating screen-based publications and note what makes them effective - or not! A woman using a public information point: You might be asked to produce an on-screen publication for an information point The crucial thing is to make sure that each publication you make is suitable for the intended purpose and audience. As with other publications in the D201 course, you donâ€™t have to worry too much about using all the advanced features of the piece of software you are using. The exam board is much more keen to see that you have thought about what you are doing and have produced a suitable solution. This will involve careful planning, testing and modifying of each product you develop.

A navigation chart is used when there is potentially more than one way to navigate through your product. For example, on a website each user may want to visit pages in a different order and on an information point, the user may want to view some sections and not others. A navigation chart starts with the main welcome screen or home page at the top and then shows the different ways a user can access the various parts of the product. There is no compulsory way of doing this. What is important is that you show you have thought about the best way to structure your product and how you are making it suitable for the intended audience. In general, a navigation chart will contain less detail than a storyboard. A storyboard shows what each screen will look like, but a navigation chart shows the possible pathways between the screens. For the products you are producing, it may be sensible to put a bit more detail on your navigation charts, so that you have a design for each page you hope to produce. Add notes to your diagram to explain exactly what you are trying to achieve. Explain the reasons for the choices you have made.

An information point is a set of screens that provide information on a particularly topic. You've probably seen information points in stations, airports, museums and places or interest. Make sure your Index page has links to all content. When you're designing an information point, it must be possible for the user to navigate to the information they want without having to scroll through all the other information. There must be a menu that provides links to all information. This can be done in a Powerpoint-type slide show or by making a set of webpages. What you choose to use is up to you. Which do feel most comfortable with? Which lets you do the job in the way that is most suitable for the purpose and audience?

Paper publications cover letters, leaflets, posters and reports. You will need to produce at least one of these for your DiDA project. When planning your publication, always keep in mind the target audience and purpose of the publication. The D201 project is split into the production of two types of publications - paper-based and screen-based. You will need to take different approaches for each publication, but it is crucial to follow a suitable format and layout for each. It is also important to ensure each publication is suitable for the intended purpose and audience. Don't worry about using all the advanced features of the software you are using. The exam board is more interested in evidence showing you have thought about what you are doing and produced a suitable solution. It is better to spend time testing your publication with a member of the intended audience and then improving it, than trying to make your project look 'flash'. You MUST produce the documents that are listed in the SPB. If a document is missed out, you will lose all nine marks! It is better to complete all the documents to a decent standard than to have one or two good ones and a few poor ones. Plan your time carefully and make sure you get all the publications made to the best of your ability. As you work through the various publications, keep coming back to the word - SOAP - a Sense Of Audience and Purpose Paper publications include posters, leaflets, newsletters and adverts

The standard layout for a business letter is shown below. It is probably best to use a Word Processor for the letter, but you could also use a Desktop Publishing Programme. You don't have to stick to exactly this format, but there is little to gain from doing much more than the basic version. The important thing is that the letter is fit for purpose. Focus on making sure the content of the letter is correct, rather than spending time putting in fancy graphics. Make sure your letter meets the purpose outlined in the SPB. Use a suitable font, nothing fancy, and definitely not a joined-up hand writing font. Use a suitable form of language. If it's a business letter, use formal, business-like language. Ask your English teacher to have a look at the letter and to check it for spelling, grammar and general content. Remember to ask them if they think it is SOAP - Suitable Of Audience and Purpose

Leaflets and newsletters are probably best tackled using a desktop publishing program such as Publisher. This will give you greater control over the layout than a Word Processor program like Word. Start by reading the SPB carefully and noting exactly what you need to produce. Keep coming back to this to make sure you have all the necessary sections. Once you are sure you have a good idea of what you want to produce, start collecting all the images you want to include. Make sure you are not breaking any copyright legislation and be sure to include the sources of the images in your acknowledgements section. Always leave time to test your publication with people who can give you sensible feedback. This could be a teacher or parent, if the publication is aimed at adults, or a classmate or younger brother/sister if the publication is aimed at children. Donâ€™t just make a note of the comments you get, act on them and make your publication as good as possible.

There are lots of different ways to produce a poster, but before you start using a package, make sure it is capable of printing out in the size needed for the SPB â€“ eg can it print A3 paper? Again it is best to start by re-reading the project brief and noting down exactly what you need to do. Donâ€™t get drawn in to designing the poster to appeal to your tastes â€“ unless you are in the target audience. The key difference between a poster and other paper-based documents is that posters must work over a greater distance. Do some research and look at posters in the real world. Which ones work the best? What is it about them that makes them work? What sort of graphics and text to do they use? A person walking past a wall covered in billboard posters. Posters have large text advertising music. Plan your poster carefully before you start. Collect all the graphics and text you will need and then start to put the whole thing together. Use a desktop publisher program such as Microsoft Publisher, but there are a lot of alternative ways of producing an effective poster. Again, it is really important to test your poster with the target audience and ensure that the whole thing is suitable for purpose.

It is likely that you will have to write a report on a survey that you carry out. This publication is probably best dealt with using a word processor. The SPB will tell you exactly what the purpose of the report is and exactly what audience you are writing for. It is likely that you will have to use a formal sort of language and a mature and serious layout. Make sure you include page numbers on the footer of pages. Check the Bitesize DiDA section on Headers and Footers for instructions.

Database reports need to be prepared in whichever database program you are using for the project (probably Microsoft Access). For instructions on producing database reports, have a look at Bitesize DiDA: Database reports . Take the same approach as you do with all your other documents and make sure reports are fit for purpose and suitable for the audience. Start by looking at them and seeing if they are easy to read â€“ often you will need to change the alignment [alignment: objects and text can be aligned left, right, centred or justified ], colour and size. You may also need to add some text to explain what the report shows. In Design View, click on the Aa button. Draw out a box and type in text explaining what the report shows and if you have any recommendations on actions to take.

Paper publications cover letters, leaflets, posters and reports. You will need to produce at least one of these for your DiDA project. When planning your publication, always keep in mind the target audience and purpose of the publication. The D201 project is split into the production of two types of publications - paper-based and screen-based. You will need to take different approaches for each publication, but it is crucial to follow a suitable format and layout for each. It is also important to ensure each publication is suitable for the intended purpose and audience. Don't worry about using all the advanced features of the software you are using. The exam board is more interested in evidence showing you have thought about what you are doing and produced a suitable solution. It is better to spend time testing your publication with a member of the intended audience and then improving it, than trying to make your project look 'flash'. You MUST produce the documents that are listed in the SPB. If a document is missed out, you will lose all nine marks! It is better to complete all the documents to a decent standard than to have one or two good ones and a few poor ones. Plan your time carefully and make sure you get all the publications made to the best of your ability. As you work through the various publications, keep coming back to the word - SOAP - a Sense Of Audience and Purpose Paper publications include posters, leaflets, newsletters and adverts The standard layout for a business letter is shown below. It is probably best to use a Word Processor for the letter, but you could also use a Desktop Publishing Programme. You don't have to stick to exactly this format, but there is little to gain from doing much more than the basic version. The important thing is that the letter is fit for purpose. Focus on making sure the content of the letter is correct, rather than spending time putting in fancy graphics. Make sure your letter meets the purpose outlined in the SPB. Use a suitable font, nothing fancy, and definitely not a joined-up hand writing font. Use a suitable form of language. If it's a business letter, use formal, business-like language. Ask your English teacher to have a look at the letter and to check it for spelling, grammar and general content. Remember to ask them if they think it is SOAP - Suitable Of Audience and Purpose Leaflets and newsletters are probably best tackled using a desktop publishing program such as Publisher. This will give you greater control over the layout than a Word Processor program like Word. Start by reading the SPB carefully and noting exactly what you need to produce. Keep coming back to this to make sure you have all the necessary sections. Once you are sure you have a good idea of what you want to produce, start collecting all the images you want to include. Make sure you are not breaking any copyright legislation and be sure to include the sources of the images in your acknowledgements section. Always leave time to test your publication with people who can give you sensible feedback. This could be a teacher or parent, if the publication is aimed at adults, or a classmate or younger brother/sister if the publication is aimed at children. Donâ€™t just make a note of the comments you get, act on them and make your publication as good as possible. There are lots of different ways to produce a poster, but before you start using a package, make sure it is capable of printing out in the size needed for the SPB â€“ eg can it print A3 paper? Again it is best to start by re-reading the project brief and noting down exactly what you need to do. Donâ€™t get drawn in to designing the poster to appeal to your tastes â€“ unless you are in the target audience. The key difference between a poster and other paper-based documents is that posters must work over a greater distance. Do some research and look at posters in the real world. Which ones work the best? What is it about them that makes them work? What sort of graphics and text to do they use? A person walking past a wall covered in billboard posters. Posters have large text advertising music. Plan your poster carefully before you start. Collect all the graphics and text you will need and then start to put the whole thing together. Use a desktop publisher program such as Microsoft Publisher, but there are a lot of alternative ways of producing an effective poster. Again, it is really important to test your poster with the target audience and ensure that the whole thing is suitable for purpose. It is likely that you will have to write a report on a survey that you carry out. This publication is probably best dealt with using a word processor. The SPB will tell you exactly what the purpose of the report is and exactly what audience you are writing for. It is likely that you will have to use a formal sort of language and a mature and serious layout. Make sure you include page numbers on the footer of pages. Check the Bitesize DiDA section on Headers and Footers for instructions. Database reports need to be prepared in whichever database program you are using for the project (probably Microsoft Access). For instructions on producing database reports, have a look at Bitesize DiDA: Database reports . Take the same approach as you do with all your other documents and make sure reports are fit for purpose and suitable for the audience. Start by looking at them and seeing if they are easy to read â€“ often you will need to change the alignment [alignment: objects and text can be aligned left, right, centred or justified ], colour and size. You may also need to add some text to explain what the report shows. In Design View, click on the Aa button. Draw out a box and type in text explaining what the report shows and if you have any recommendations on actions to take.

You should already have read the notes on Questionnaires before starting this section. After you've collected your data, you will need to display your results using charts and graphs. The final part of your survey will then be to interpret the data and explain any patterns and trends. When you have collected all your survey data, you will need to type it into the spreadsheet before you can analyse it. In the example below, the questions have been put across the top and each person's answer has gone into a new row. The results are from a survey of parents about their children's internet and TV use. It may be easier to enter the data if you make a form. Put the questions along the top row, then click Data and then Form

How concerned are you about your childâ€™s use of the internet (0 not worried at all, 5 extremely worried)? The average value for this was 3.88. Here is a graph showing the information. Pie chart showing how worried parents are by their children's internet use The most common answer given was 5 â€“ extremely concerned. This shows that many parents are really concerned about the effects of the internet on children. More than three quarters of those surveyed were quite concerned. This gives the basic facts from the questionnaire, and then adds some description to what the data shows. Sometimes this may be as much as you can do, but do try to look carefully and come up with reasons for the data and try to draw some conclusions.

The most common answer given was 5 â€“ extremely concerned. This shows that many parents are really concerned about the effects of the internet on children. More than three quarters of those surveyed were quite concerned. Pie chart showing how worried parents are by their children's internet use When I looked at the data more carefully, I found that of the 23 people who said they were extremely concerned about their childrenâ€™s use of the internet, 18 were the parents of teenage girls who used chat rooms regularly. Part of the reason parents were so worried was because of the reports of a girl being abducted in the local area after using a chat room. It should also be noted that less than 20 per cent of those surveyed used any sort of web filtering or reporting system and had no idea what their children were using the internet for. This fact might add to their concerns. The school could offer parents a session on safe use of the internet and show how easy it is to install software that controls and logs access to the internet. They could also add a page to the website offering further advice and links. This gives the basic facts from the questionnaire, and then adds some description of what the data shows. It then goes on to interpret the meaning of the data and explore the factors influencing the data. Finally, there is a paragraph that includes some recommendations based on the findings of the report.

Once you have your data in a spreadsheet, you can start to analyse it and produce your report. It is really important to read through the SPB [SPB: Summative Project Brief - the project brief set by Edexcel and the means by which your attainment is assessed. ] and to understand the purpose and audience for the questionnaire report. In your spreadsheet, you should leave all the raw data [raw data: data which has not been processed for use ] on a separate sheet called results. Go to Insert [insert: usually located on the main menu located at the top of the page. ], then Worksheet to create new worksheet pages. Each graph or chart you create should be on a separate worksheet. You can change the name of worksheets by double clicking on the tabs at the bottom. Right click on the tabs to rename, change colour or insert a new worksheet

There are several different statistical techniques you can use to analyse your results once they have been entered into a spreadsheet. If the answer was a number, you could calculate the average using the average function. The forumale = Average (C2:C13) has been entered into cell D2. You can use the functions max [max: a function which is used to determine the highest value within a specified range ] and min [min: a function which is used to determine the lowest value within a specified range ] to get the highest and lowest values in a block of cells. You can get the range by using a formula that takes the min away from the max. The range is the difference between the minimum (lowest) and maximum (highest) numbers in a list. Calculate the range by using a formula that takes the min away from the max. The range is the difference between the maximum and minumum value.

The easiest way to get the data ready for the charts is to use the Countif function. For more instructions about creating charts and graphs, visit the Bitesize DiDA: Spreadsheets section. Donâ€™t go overboard with colours and patterns when making graphs. Just make sure that every graph is readable. It is OK to use colours because your report will be viewed on screen in your eportfolio. You do not have to make graphs and charts readable in black and white. Sometimes, your graphs will not work well if you use categories like 0,1,2,3,4,5. The spreadsheet interprets them a bit differently and your graphs come out looking wrong. One way to get around this is to use the words instead, ie zero, one, two, three, four, five. Make sure your graphs have sensible titles and legends (labels). Always check this, look carefully and change them if necessary. It is usually easiest to choose the option to insert the chart as a new sheet. This will make it easier when it comes to copying and pasting the graphs into your survey report. Test your graphs to make sure they make sense. Again, it is a good idea to ask a maths or science teacher if they have any comments or suggestions â€“ listen to them carefully â€“ they are experts!

How concerned are you about your childâ€™s use of the internet (0 not worried at all, 5 extremely worried)? The average value for this was 3.88. Here is a graph showing the information. Pie chart showing how worried parents are by their children's internet use This gives the basic facts from the questionnaire, but there is no analysis or interpretation of the information. It is OK as a starting point, but you can produce a much better report with only a little bit more work.

Before setting to work on your questions, check the list below of things to avoid. Also, avoid questions that could be interpreted [interpreted: the way something is understood ] in several different ways. Quantifiers such as â€˜fewâ€™, â€˜someâ€™, â€˜manyâ€™ and â€˜usuallyâ€™ can be interpreted differently by different respondents. Therefore, great care must be taken when using such words or, alternatively, avoid using them. Are you ready to start writing your questionnaire? First, have a go at the interactive activity below to see if you can identify a good, poor or biased questionnaire question.

This type of question will give you clear results that are easy to convert into statistics. An example of a yes/no question Tick boxes give people a limited choice of answers. This makes interpreting results easier, but you must check that all possible answers are included in the tick boxes. One word answers are given. This type of question can be used if it's difficult to predict all the possible different answers. This type of question is useful for finding out people's opinions about something. However, sentence answers can be difficult to analyse.

Carefully select your sample group to ensure you collect a generalised view of the population you're researching. Selecting a suitable sample size will not necessarily be exactly representative of the whole group because all sample participants are not the same. Sampling [sampling: the number of subjects included in the study ] choices are probably more important than the overall number of people you question. It is essential to give your survey to the right people. If you are supposed to find out what parents think about something, make sure you give your survey to parents! Read the SPB [SPB: Summative Project Brief - the project brief set by Edexcel and the means by which your attainment is assessed. ] carefully to make sure you know what you have to do. Consider what type of sampling you intend to do. Try to make sure your questionnaire is representative. If you are supposed to be finding out what young people think about something, make sure you ask roughly equal numbers of boys and girls. If you ask just boys, your survey results will be inaccurate. For a more detailed description of sampling techniques, take a look at GCSE Bitesize Maths: Data sampling

Some searches can produce hundreds of results pages linking to websites that are not relevant to your search. To avoid this happening, be careful when choosing your search words. The more specific your words are, the better your search results will be. Follow the tips below to improve your search results. Use quotation marks to search for a phrase of several words together. Avoid using words that are not relevant in your searches. Including words like 'how, and, in, to or as' in a search will give a list of irrelevant search results. Only use the names of people, places or things that you want to find. Only include the important words - Oxford museums Use the + sign to search for webpages with more than one key word. Use the + sign to search for webpages with more than one key word. Adding a plus to your search will ensure that all your results include the key words. Include a -sign against words you don't want included in search results Put a - sign in front of any words that you don't want to be included in your search results. For example, you might want to search for information about the place Wimbledon, but not not about tennis. To practise more searching techniques [searching techniques: techniques which make searching for information on the Internet easier ], visit BBC Webwise.

Some search engines, eg Google allow you to search for images using key words. You can use exactly the same search techniques used for searching for websites. You must remember that if you use images that are owned by other people, you could be breaking copyright lawcopyright law: The law which makes it illegal for a person to copy an item such as a magazine article, a photo or a CD without the agreement of the copyright owner.. For more information on copyright, visit Bitesize DiDA: Image copyright. Many websites offer free use of images and photographs for students. BBC Schools allow students to use images from the BBC Schools website for educational purposes. Check the BBC Schools Copyright page for more information. Below is a list of websites that offer free images.

Statistical information is based on a study of the number of times something happens or is present. Often, the government carries out large research projects to collect information about people and their lives. These results are often available on the internet and can be used in your DiDA research project. Statistics can be used to back up or prove a point. For example, if you wanted to say that the village you live in has a high crime rate, you could prove this by quoting statistics for the number of crimes committed in a year. In the UK, the census is a massive survey sent to every household in the country. A census is carried out every ten years and is the main source of statistics on income, housing, health and employment. It's important to use accurate statistics in your DiDA project. Make sure you use statistics from an official website and, if possible, compare figures with other sources. Listed below are some useful websites providing statistics. Don't forget to include the source of your statistics in the bibiography.

Most websites found on the internet don't belong to companies or organisations. Many people publish websites as a hobby or for political reasons. It's often quite easy to spot an unofficial website [unofficial website: a site that is not produced by or belongs to an 'official' company or organisation ]. You can often spot whether a website is unofficial by looking at its address. The more you use the web, the more familiar you'll become with different URLs. You can usually tell that a website is produced by an unofficial source just by looking at the website design. Most websites include a 'last updated' date. Always check this. Some websites haven't been updated for years and information may be completely out of date. Daily news - last updated 04/07/2003 Some unofficial websites can be useful for finding out people's opinions. Websites about hobbies, music and travel often provide valuable advice and opinions about everything from restaurant to gig reviews.

You'll find that each time you use the internet, you will visit many different websites. Some you will only look at briefly and decide it's not what you were looking for, other times you will find valuable websites that you will want to visit regularly throughout the DiDA course. Don't risk losing the web address of a really useful website. If you find a useful website, make sure you add it to your list of favourites. Remember to organise your favourites into folders. You could have a folder for each of your GCSE subjects and sub folders for topics. If you forget to add a useful website to your favourites, use the History button to find a website again.

Website designs vary from basic ones set up by users as a hobby to sophisticated designs that represent large international companies. Before designing a website, you should take a look at other websites to help you decide how your webpages should look. You should also read the project brief carefully. Make sure you do exactly what the examiners want. There is no point in doing any more - if they say five pages, only do five pages. Normally, on a website there is a title bar at the top, a menu on the left and then the main information appears in the big space on the right. Stick to a simple, clear page layout Try to avoid flashy things like sound, scrolling banners and animated text/graphics. These might look 'cool' to you, but, unless they are really suitable for the purpose and audience, they are more likely to lose you marks than earn you marks.

Images on websites can improve the look and style of the page. However, you must be careful to save images in the correct format. The two main formats for web images are gif and jpg. These are used for images that have only a few colours, such as line drawings, text and logos. These are used for images or photographs that include details and more colours. If you save a photo or graphic in the incorrect format, how the image looks will be affected. Look at the images below. When the fish photo is saved in a gif format, colours and details are lost. When the bitesize graphic is saved incorrectly as a jpg, unwanted colours appear and the looks less sharp. Look closely at the orange background - the image looks speckled. Look closely at the orange background - the image looks speckled.

Cropping allows you to select the part of the image you want to show. It's likely that you may take a photograph or find an image that is too big and you only want to use one part of the image. To crop an image, you can use image editing software such as Word, Photoshop or Paintshop. 1. Crop this image to include only the penguin. 2. Select the crop tool in a picture editing package. 3. Use the crop tool to outline the part of the image you want to keep. Adjust the size of the area to be cropped by dragging on the boxes on the selection border. 4. To crop the image, press the return key on your keyboard or double click in the centre of the selected area of the image.

The examiners will be looking for a consistent house style throughout each publication you produce. A good example of this can be seen on the BBC GCSE Bitesize website. GCSE Bitesize uses the same font, sizes and layout throughout the site. This gives a much more professional impression than constantly chopping and changing between different pages. Ideally, you should come up with a few ideas for fonts, layouts and colour schemes and then test them on members of your target audience. Remember to include details of this testing when writing your reviews and evaluations. Always remember the publication has to appeal to your target audience! Take a look at the image below. It's a classic example of a badly designed website! Make sure you avoid using garish colours and patterned backgrounds.

It is crucial to thoroughly test your presentations and websites, as well as all the publications you produce. First, check that all the links work. It is best to copy the website or presentation onto another device (like a memory stick or CD) and try it out away from the school network - this will show if you have used absolute hyperlinks by mistake. All the links must work before you submit your work for marking and moderation. Secondly, test your publication with members of the target audience. One good way of doing this is to prepare a checklist for the reviewer to fill in. Finally, write the results of your tests in the review section of your eportfolio. Remember to say how well your publication meets the needs of the audience and include ideas on how it can be improved.

Tables are really useful for organising and displaying information. Most word processing packages allow you to insert tables into your document. You then need to enter the number of rows and the number of columns you would like your table to have. Remember that rows go across the page, and columns go down the page. The table will then appear in your word processing document. A table with three columns and two rows.

This Revision Bite explores the different drama mediums used in drama exploration. You'll use several of these strategies for your portfolio work in Drama Exploration Unit 1 and Drama Exploration Unit 2. There are drama medium video examples and activities throughout this Revision Bite. Student in costume and make-up Costume can be modern clothes, period costume or a fantasy outfit. You may want to wear full costume, or perhaps just wear black, with indications of character as an extra feature. For example, a hat, shawl or jacket could signify character. Sometimes, in stylised drama, the items of costume are exaggerated - so a jacket could be in very bright colours. Masks may be single colour, painted, full-face or half-face. They are usually used in stylised work to indicate non-human characters - for example in a Greek chorus, in 'Animal Farm', or in a play with demons. Make-up functions in different ways. Sometimes it's used to 'age' an actor, or it may indicate a fantasy character such as a fairy in 'A Midsummer Night's Dream'. At other times it can alter the gender of a character, or communicate a different style of theatre, eg Kabuki [kabuki: A style of theatre, popular in Japan, often featuring elaborate costumes, music and dancing ]. Use the dressing room activity to design and print costumes for your character. Remember to check out the costume gallery and the hats, wigs, masks and make-up gallery.

As well as helping the actors to be seen, lighting can also indicate the time of day, or a place, and can focus audience attention on a character. Spot - has a hard-edged effect, used to light characters or elements on the stage. Coloured filters can be used with this lamp. Fresnel - used for a softer edged effect, with a diffusing lens in front of the lamp. It's useful for good overall light, when used with others. Coloured filters can be used with this lamp. Flood - produces a clear wide-angled light, but there is little control over the spread of the light. Coloured filters can be used with this lamp. Strobe - a flashing light, used for special effects. Often used to give the effect of old movies. Produces a jerky effect on the movements of actors when used on its own.

You may use very simple or very detailed sets and props. Stage sets help create the background to a drama, but it's usually best to keep them simple. Shakespeare's stage used little in the way of set, and the modern trend is also to keep things low-key. Props are the items that are held or used by an actor in a scene to make it more realistic. These are also best kept to the minimum. A briefcase might be enough to portray a businessman, without using a phone as well, or a hat might signify one character when it's on and a different character when it's off. Hint - if you use props in your drama, start working with them as soon as you can. Props can slow down the action at times, and you'll need lots of practise if you want a slick pace.

The use of climax and anti-climax (the building and releasing of tension) in a drama is crucial, as it creates a sense of expectation in the audience. We can become incredibly tense as we wait to see what's going to happen in a play, and then we're relieved when things turn out well. It all adds to an interesting experience. Climax building up in 'Eastenders' For example, will the guard notice that the escape tunnel entrance is partly uncovered? If the action is slowed down - perhaps because he sits down and talks for a while - the tension rises as we watch him. If the guard leaves without noticing the tunnel, the tension releases and we sigh with relief. It's up to the director of a drama to create the climax and anti-climax that make sure this happens.

The use of contrast in drama productions - eg stillness contrasted with activity, or silence contrasted with noise - is a useful way to focus the audience's attention. A drama being played with no change of pace or rhythm doesn't usually hold our interest, but most can be brought to life with the use of contrasting sights and sounds. An example of such contrast could be in a courtroom drama. At first there's the hustle and bustle of bringing in the prisoner, with everyone scurrying around trying to see and hear the judge's pronouncement. Then there's the sound of the gavel banging on his desk - and the resulting quiet before he pronounces the sentence. The audience can't fail to be interested!

The way an actor plays a role, using his/her acting skills to create a character in a drama, is known as characterisation. Think about how we describe someone. Of course everyone looks a bit different, but a person's character can be shown in many ways, and this is where the actor's skill comes in. You can show a character in the way they walk and move (body language [body language: The non-verbal way in which a person communicates their physical and mental state through using facial expressions, gesture and posture ]), in the way they speak (vocal qualities) and in their reaction to events in the drama. When creating a character we may use techniques such as hot-seating [hot-seating: To question an individual while they remain in character ] to develop the role, but we also need to think about these other aspects of presenting the character so they can 'come alive' within the drama. Watch the video example by clicking on the link. Note: this link will open in a new browser window.

Thought-tracking helps inform an audience about a character. Sometimes in daily life we would like to know what someone thinks at important moments. We really want to know how people have been affected by a situation. When we know more of what they are feeling, we understand them better. In drama, too, when we know more of what a character thinks or feels, the drama is deepened and the audience becomes more involved. Play thought-tracking video example Watch the video example by clicking on the link opposite. Note: this link will open in a new browser window.

Role-play is what you do when you're pretending to be another person and using your imagination to speak, think and even feel like that character. If you don't pretend to be someone else while acting in a drama, then the audience will see only 'you' and not the character you are meant to be portraying. They will only see 'you' in the situations that are described. If you make the role-play realistic and believable, then the audience will be more likely to 'suspend their disbelief' (forget that they're watching a drama, and feel personally involved). Play role-play with thought-tracking video example Watch the video example by clicking on the link. Note: this link will open in a new browser window.

Hot-seating is a way of developing (or deepening) character. If you are in the hot-seat you answer questions from others in the group while you are 'in role'. The characters will seem more realistic if you feel you really 'know' them. It is easier to be spontaneous and believable if you have carefully explored a character in your drama during the hot-seating process. Play hot-seating with cross-cutting video example Watch the video example by clicking on the link. Note: this link will open in a new browser window.

Forum theatre is a technique you can use while acting out a scene. The group watching is encouraged to stop the action when they think it necessary, to suggest a different action. At other times, the actors themselves can stop the action, and ask for help. Sometimes someone else can step in and take over a role - or even introduce a new one. Sometimes it is hard, when devising drama, to imagine what a character might do or say at a particular moment. If you stop the drama when in role, and ask for help from your group, someone will probably give you a good idea of what to do or say next. They might also offer to take over the role to try out their idea - or even join the scene as another character altogether, to take things in a new direction. Watch the video example by clicking on the link. Note: this link will open in a new browser window.

This Revision Bite covers different types of drama texts - also known as stimuli. These range from poetry extracts to TV drama, and you'll be using them in Drama Exploration Unit 1. We'll also cover specific play texts, for use in Drama Exploration Unit 2. In Drama Exploration Unit 1, you'll be given a range of drama texts. Sometimes these are called stimuli [stimuli: things that set off a reaction in the nervous system - for example, light, heat, sound, gravity, smell, taste, or temperature. The singular is stimulus ], as they're intended to stimulate a response in you, which will help give you ideas for your drama work. Photographs, paintings, masks, props, costumes, sculptures, art objects. Evil Angel: Go forward, Faustus, in that famous art. Good Angel: Sweet Faustus, leave that execrable art. Faustus: Contrition, prayer, repentance - what of these? Good Angel: O, they are means to bring thee unto heaven! Evil Angel: Rather illusions, fruits of lunacy, That make men foolish that do use them most. Good Angel: Sweet Faustus, think of heaven and heavenly things. Evil Angel: No, Faustus; think of honour and of wealth. [Exeunt Angels. ]Faustus: Wealth! Why, the signiory of Embden shall be mine. When Mephistophilis shall stand by me, What power can hurt me? Family, with children wearing gas mask boxes Clothing through the war era was practical, and affected by the rationing system. New clothes were often just re-fashioned from old clothes, and there were shortages of luxurious materials such as silk. Women would often wear a simple knee-length dress or blouse and skirt. Mackintosh coats were popular outdoor items, and some women would wear a matching tailored suit jacket outdoors. Men continued to wear jackets and ties as a matter of routine, although sometimes with casual trousers, not necessarily matching suit trousers. Jumpers, vests and polo-neck shirts were popular for less formal wear.

Costume of a geisha, close-up Costume of a geisha, full-length If your play is based in Japan, you might want a costume for a traditional geisha - a female Japanese entertainer. They wear white make-up on their face, with bright red lips. A geisha always wears a kimono (a traditional full-length robe). The traditional dress for an Indian woman is a sari - a large piece of cloth that can be wrapped around the body in various styles. The most common style of wearing a sari is wrapped around the waist, with one end draped over the shoulder. Most women wear a short-sleeved blouse underneath. Traditional clothing for Indian men includes a knee-length (or longer) shirt (note women may also wear these). It's usually worn over loose trousers. Traditional african dress, worn in a variety of ways Traditional African costume varies widely across the continent, although there are some similarities. Tunics or kaftans (long shirts, usually to the floor) are popular clothing for men, worn with loose trousers. Women may wear toga-inspired garments, wrapped around their bodies. Bright coloured fabrics and beaded jewellery are popular. African warriors sometimes wear fantastically decorated costumes, and paint their bodies.

The Tudor period (1485-1603) was a time in English history that remains strong in the popular imagination to this day. Two of the most famous Tudors, often recreated in drama today, are Queen Elizabeth I and her father Henry VIII. Rather like today, the wealthy people of the period would wear clothes made from luxurious materials such as silk, and bright colours. The middle-classes would wear clothes of a similar style but usually made from cheaper materials, such as wool and linen. Poorer people would wear simple clothes made from wool - tunic and trousers for men, and a long dress (worn with an apron on top) for women. Well-to-doTudor women wore hooped skirts with padded hips, which reached to the floor. Men wore padded breeches with stockings - not trousers. Fur was a popular trim among the wealthy. One of the most recognised items of clothing from the late Tudor period is the ruff - a collar of lace worn around the neck. Some wealthy people wore enormous ruffs to show off their wealth.

The following images are from the BBC adaptation of Jane Austen's 'Pride and Prejudice'. The book was first published in 1813. In the later 18th century women adopted a more loosely fitting dress, known as the chemise, which was inspired by the fashions of ancient Greece and Rome. The dresses were often made of muslin, in plain colours, with a high waistline. This trend continued throughout the early 19th century. For men, knee-length breeches were replaced by ankle-length trousers, and suits became more fashionable. Clothing among the wealthy classes during this period became far less flamboyant in style and colour than they had been previously.

These images show the clothes worn for the BBC production 'The Virgin Queen' about Queen Elizabeth I. Notice how the clothes from her early life are simpler than those she wore later on. Wealthy women of the 18th century still wore corsets to help shape their clothes, and hooped dresses were still popular, but the dresses were more low-cut than previously. Wealthy men continued to wear three-quarter-length coats and breeches. Wigs, high-heeled shoes (worn by men and women) and elaborate embroidery were big trends of the early 18th century, but they disappeared towards the end of the period. Hems rose, waistlines dropped, corsets disappeared and elaborate bead work became popular on dresses. Middle-class men still wore suits, ties and waistcoats during the day, and the better-off would often change into a formal suit for dinner in the evening. For women, a full skirt with netting became fashionable, while the Teddy Boy look became popular with young men. The look consisted of tight fitting jeans/trousers (sometimes called drainpipes), a long smart jacket and a thin tie. These young men often wore their hair in a quiff (in homage to Elvis Presley). This period also saw the introduction of the hippy - often a young middle-class person in favour of colourful flowing clothes, peace and free love. Facial expressions are important in drama. They can convey emotions, develop the story and communicate the feelings and thoughts of the characters to the audience. Actors may use any combination of facial expression, gestures, movement and props to create the effect they want. Browse through this gallery to see some expressions used in drama. Actors can show happiness by smiling, laughing and making gestures such as hugging each other. Actors can show sadness in a drama by crying, looking thoughtful, or using comforting gestures with each other. Actors can show emotional pain and grief by crying, shouting in anguish, or holding their head in their hands. They can show physical pain by facial expressions and gestures. Actors can show shock and horror by using facial expressions such as raised eyebrows, an open mouth and gestures such as throwing their arms up in the air. Showing shock, comedy style Actors can use similar, but less exaggerated, versions of the gestures of shock and horror when they want to show surprise only. Showing surprise, comedy style Actors can convey anger and aggression by facial expressions and by aggressive gestures towards the camera or other characters. Showing physical aggression, comedy style Actors can communicate insanity by looking dishevelled, adopting a wide-eyed stare, or brandishing weapons menacingly . Actors can show worry through facial expressions and gestures such as biting their nails. Actors often create a sense of excitement or anticipation by looking off-stage, sometimes open-mouthed. Showing anticipation by looking off-stage Actors can purse their lips, furrow their brow and focus intently on what they are doing to convey concentration. When actors need to reflect on-stage about dramatic events, they can show a thoughtful mood by their facial expression, by gestures such as resting their face on their hands, or by looking into the distance. Actors can show exasperation through facial expressions, through jumping up and down, or by use of props. Actors can grab food or other props hungrily, and seem to gobble it down, to convey greed.

There are lots of different styles of make-up - if you use make-up for your drama, it will depend on the theme and style you're planning. Look through this page for inspiration. When you're on stage, performing under hot bright lights, you should wear some basic make-up, whether you're a boy or a girl! Heavy foundation is useful for preventing the skin from looking washed-out under the lights, and face powder helps keep shine to a minimum. You may also want to use eyeliner to define the eyes. White face powder was popular in the 16th-18th centuries, partly to cover up bad skin caused by lack of washing. Having elizabethan-style make-up applied Actress in 18th-century-style white powder make-up Today, a lot of women (and some men) wear make-up every day, but it's often quite discreet. If your drama is set in modern times, it's unlikely you'll want to go over the top with make-up. Think about your character and their personality before you decide how heavily you want to apply it. The natural make-up look The heavy make-up look Some people wear a certain type of make-up to reflect a popular movement (eg gothic style make-up) or profession (eg a Japanese geisha girl). Make-up can also be used to create the look of an injury or bruise, or to create a horror effect. When you're devising drama, you'll need to think about how to stage your performance, and what type of stage to use. You'll also need to think about stage directions for each character in your drama. This Revision Bite defines the various types of stages, and different areas of the stage. A stage where the audience sits on one side only is called a proscenium stage (you might know this as end-on staging). The audience faces one side of the stage directly, and normally sits at a lower height. An in-the-round stage is positioned at the centre of the audience - ie there is audience around the whole stage. This type of stage creates quite an intimate atmosphere, and is good for drama that needs audience involvement. A stage where the audience sits on two sides is called a traverse stage. Again, this type of stage is good for creating an intimate atmosphere.

If you've chosen Option b: Performance Support for Paper 2, you'll need to choose an area of theatre-craft to work in. Being a designer involves plenty of creative energy, so do pick something you're passionate about. In this Revision Bite you'll find lots of tips and ideas for each of the performance support options available. With each of these you need to work closely with the group performing the drama. It's important you're in touch with their ideas about what what they want their drama to show. At first you'll be listening and perhaps offering ideas. Do take notes, so you can chart the thinking of the group as it develops. It would be good to take photographs of the group working at various stages, as these will show what was happening while you worked out your design. Research is important. You may have to research historical aspects of the subject, and look at fashion and clothing. Or you may need to look at living conditions in order to create the right light effects - would a hovel be dark, would a Victorian mansion be candle or gas-lit? Or you may want to create some sound tapes to represent traffic noise or rural sounds. The important thing is always to refer to the script [script: The text of a play or drama production - usually the script will give suggestions for the setting of the scene and contain direction for the characters ]. The starting point for all your work is the script, and everything you do should support the performance.

When thinking about costumes in a drama, your starting point should be the script or devised work. This should be in your mind at all times - you are designing for the play, and your work should support the piece. Watch what the actors have to do during the drama. If there's lots of action, their clothes must be easy to move in. For quick costume changes, you'll need easy fastenings. Research the era of the drama, or research fantasy costumes if your drama's a fantasy. Make full use of libraries and the internet to find examples of all sorts of costumes - you could start with the costume and character galleries in this section for ideas and references. Costume sketch for a character from the programme 'Dr Who'. Note the annotations and fabric sample attached. If the lighting designer is using coloured gels, experiment with how colours are affected by them. Red, for example, under red lights, looks washed out, while under blue lights it can look almost black. So choose your colours with care! First make sure your lighting rig and controls are at least the minimum requirements of the examination. Check with your teacher if you're not sure. When thinking about lighting, your starting point should be the script or devised work. This should be in your mind at all times - you're designing lighting for the play and what you do should support the piece. Find out what the actors plan to do during the drama. They might need areas of the stage lit separately, or sidelights for a particular scene or moment, or single spots to highlight particular characters. Also remember to plan for positioning, use of barn doors [barn door: A lighting device that reduces a light beam and reduces stray scatter light ], gobos [gobo: A lighting device that creates patterns of projected light on the stage ], filters etc. Research the era the drama is set in. Make full use of libraries and the internet to find examples of what life was like at the time. Your drama may be set in a time when people used oil lamps, for example, and you should work out how to create this type of light. Create a slideshow presentation with the major stages of your work outlined. This is a good way to organise your thinking, and you can practice your timing. To learn more about making a slideshow presentation, check out the Presentations Revision Bite from the Bitesize DiDA section. Keep your notebooks ready for the examiner, so you can show your designs and images not used in the slideshow. Why not mark your best pages? Be prepared to show at least two lighting states and a good transition between the two, explaining what effect you intended to create.

When thinking about stage design, your starting point should be the script or devised work. This should be in your mind at all times - you're designing a set for the play, and what you do should support the piece. Find out what the actors you're designing for actually do in the drama. Where do they walk, sit, stand? Do they use areas of the stage separately? Will they be using levels? Discuss how the group will use the stage area. Research the era in which the drama is set. Use your library and the internet to find examples of what life was like at the time. Discuss with the actors what the important elements of the piece are, so that your design reflects these. Think about creating a slideshow presentation with the major stages of your work outlined. This is a good way to organise your thinking, and you can practice to make sure that your timing is right. When thinking about sound design, your starting point should be the script or devised work. This should be in your mind at all times - you're designing the sound effects for the play, and what you do should support the piece. Find out what the actors are going to be doing in the drama. Do they need to answer a phone, for example? It can be hard to start and stop a phone on a tape or CD, so do practice with the actor.Question the group members carefully about what sounds are needed for the piece. You'll need to create them yourself, or find CDs, tapes or sound files to use. And you might need some music for the start and finish. Research the era in which the drama is to be set if the work is not fantasy. Use the library and the internet to obtain examples of what life was like at the time. For example, if the piece is set during the First World War, you'll need sound effects that link to the era. If you're working on a fantasy drama, you'll need sound that's not connected with any particular era. Think about creating a slideshow presentation with the major stages of your work outlined. This is a good way to organise your thinking, and you can practice to make sure that your timing is right. It's also a good idea to provide a sample CD or tape of ideas that you tried out during your design process. The Selfish Driver doesn't see or hear anyone else on the road, and takes more than their share of the space. This sort of behaviour stops others from feeling involved. The others realise their ideas will not be noticed or used, and they stop bothering to think. In this way the group is weakened. The Sleepy Passenger is a different kind of drain. They don't contribute much to the drama process and they have to be told what to do.

In Unit 1, you may submit all or part of your script in your portfolio. The script will need to be well annotated to get good marks. Also, in your drama performance work, annotations in your script will help you perform well. In this Revision Bite, you'll learn the basics of script annotation. To annotate means to add explanation and notes. You can annotate lots of things - a book, an image, an artefact - but annotation is used most often on scripts. Annotations help actors perform your scene exactly how you imagined it. Your annotations may start as simple one word notes, but after several rehearsals, you may need to write more detail.

The example below shows the script with annotations. Colonel Shaw is seated at his desk. The stage contains a desk, DSL (down stage left), at which Colonel Shaw sits. He has a worried expression and is tapping the top of the desk with a pencil. A knocking sound is followed by the entrance of Private Halliwell. Pt Halliwell: (Saluting) You wanted to see me, Sir? Halliwell approaches the desk and salutes, then stands to attention before speaking. His voice is clipped and neutral. Col Shaw: Yes, Halliwell. I want your account of what happened in the guardroom. Col Shaw looks up at Halliwell, hands folded on the top of the desk. Pt Halliwell: (Pause) Well, Sir, I went on duty at 16.00 hours, and they had the prisoner tied to a chair, Sir. (Silence) At this, Shaw looks down to his hands. When Halliwell becomes silent he looks up again, and leans forward slightly before speaking. Col Shaw: Go on, Halliwell. Pt Halliwell: Well, Sir, they ... they ... had the dog on a leash, Sir, and it was ... it was ... (He falters) Halliwell clears his throat before speaking, clearly nervous. Col Shaw: Please carry on, Halliwell. Col Shaw continues to watch him. Pt Halliwell: ... it was up at the prisoner's throat, Sir, and was growling, and its teeth were bared. Halliwell takes a deep breath before continuing. Col Shaw: Who was holding the animal? After Halliwell's statement there is a silence. Shaw gets up out of his chair and goes to the window, down stage. Looking towards the audience, he appears thoughtful and is still looking out while asking the questions. Halliwell licks his lips before answering. Col Shaw: Mmm. (Thoughtful) Did you see the dog actually bite the prisoner, Halliwell? Shaw is still facing the audience, with his back to Halliwell. Pt Halliwell: (Silence) In the silence, Shaw turns to face Halliwell, before speaking in a low threatening voice, staring intently at Halliwell. Col Shaw: Answer the question, Halliwell?

Here's an example of a student's annotated script, from her portfolio. Click on the link below to view the script. Open Alex's script (PDF file 1.2 mb) As you can see, Alex has used a light blue font for her annotations. The character, Becky, uses a language register that marks out her monologue [monologue: An extended speech performed by one person only ] as different from the language of the bullying girls. This is excellent, as it tells the audience that these are her inner feelings about the other girls. The student's annotation shows exactly how to stage the scene, with a coloured font to make it show up. In addition, the scene itself is well structured, showing the build-up to the action and finally leaving the stage clear of everyone except Becky. Now the audience are able to think about what happened, and will realise what her feelings are likely to be.

We were trying to show one character being teased and taunted by others. We wanted to show that what was happening was upsetting to the victim. During the sequence we chanted insults, which gradually became louder. The character at the front is the victim, and he shows this by his facial expression (he is looking downwards with a hurt expression) and his body language, which shows tension. The bullies stand behind him so that they can be seen by the audience. They are leaning in towards him as they chant insults. Their faces show cruel laughter and sneering. There could be a small alteration of the sequence, with the actor at the centre of the bullies standing a little taller. This could still have shown the audience that the bullies were more powerful, but the character would have been seen more clearly by all of the audience. A clear sense of the candidate knowing what the scene is supposed to show, and how that has been achieved. The possible improvement given shows that the candidate is aware of how the sequence will be seen by the audience. Overall, clear explanations and a solid sense that the candidate knows how and why the sequence was effective. Check out more body language in the Expressions gallery.

By using the What?Â Why? and How? technique, you can find all the detail you need to include in your portfolio [portfolio: A collection of your work, completed over the duration of your studies ]. Here's an example of how to do it, based on the exercise on the previous page. Our teacher asked us to create a still image of the moment when the boy confronted the girl spreading the rumours about him. She wanted us to be able to show the moment when the boy found his own inner strength to do something about the rumours. We decided that we needed to show clearly the impact of his anger on the girl, and that she should suddenly realise that she can't push him around any longer. The actor playing the role of the girl showed in her body language and facial expression that she was shocked that he'd found out it was her who was spreading the rumours. She had to show tension in her body, and made her eyes open wider than usual to show panic. This was to communicate to the audience the impact of the confrontation on her, to show that she was both shocked and a little scared of what was going to happen. When writing about a still image, it's a good idea to use an image, diagram or stick man drawing to show how the still image was performed.

With audience on two sides, characters 1 and 2 enter at one end of the traverse, and speak their lines. They smile broadly at each other, and 'freeze'. Character 3 enters at the opposite end, and says his/her line with the attitude of someone intending to shock. Characters 1 and 2 react by turning their heads towards 3, with shock registering on their faces. Spotlights come up on each character as they speak their lines. Characters 1 and 2 should react to 3's declaration, so that there is a brief tableau after 3 speaks. The characters are not on levels. The characters come into the acting area one by one, and just stand facing two sections of the audience. During their entrances, car engine sound effects can be played. When this has stopped, the actors speak the lines. For more about the areas of the stage, read the stage Revision Bite in the Performing section.

After each character has said their opening line, what do you want the audience to be thinking? They'll probably presume that the cause of the accident is character 3. A twist could be that one of the other characters caused the accident. It's for you to decide who this might be, and create a character that suits your version of events. In the opening lines there's a hint that something unusual has happened. It's for you to choose who this has happened to, and why. If the drama is to work well, the audience has to feel some empathy [empathy: An awareness and understanding of another person's feelings, situation or motives. ] for the characters, so they care what happens to them. To make this happen, you need to focus the drama on the characters. Hot-seating [hot-seating: To question an individual while they remain in character ] the characters could reveal important information about them, and provide ideas for scenes that help an audience get to know them. When developing scenes for your drama, decide whether you want the characters to have met before the drama starts. For example, could the Ghanaian doctor have treated character 3 for injuries he got when he was fighting drunk? Could character 3 have met character 1 when his gang caused trouble at the club at an earlier time? This is a way of showing that the two characters had met before, little knowing that their paths would cross again. At the same time you can show something of what they're like.

Here are some ideas about how you can stage the important, central, accident scene. Character 3 and two friends are driving along (stage this with two characters standing in a spotlight with the third character leaning into the space between their heads and shoulders). They are laughing and shouting. The 'car' stops and the two friends exit leaving 3 alone. The action freezes, and the lights go up on the other side of stage. Character 1 is shouting off-stage, having an argument with her husband. She crosses the stage, grabbing her car keys as she goes. Character 2 is at home, when the sound of a crash outside is heard. He goes to the 'window' and looks out. He mimes picking up a phone, and gives details of the scene he can see outside. He says he's a doctor and will go to help. Blackout. When the lights come on again, the sound of loud music is heard and two bodies are seen, lying awkwardly - one on the ground the other on the chairs as if in a car. Character 2 approaches the bodies and leans into the 'car' to turn off the radio. Silence. Character 2 looks at the two bodies, and bends down to check for signs of life. He starts making the accident victims more comfortable. Character 3 starts moaning, character 2 tells him that the ambulance will soon be here. Freeze. Using physical theatre [physical theatre: A mime technique in which actors use their bodies to create props or part of the set ], the characters 1 and 3 are drivers of cars made up of the other actors. Each 'vehicle' faces the audience, and each is lit by a spotlight, with the rest of the stage in darkness. The actors making up the vehicles can make the sound of the cars, gear-changing etc. Character 1 is angry and driving badly. She talks about her husband and their argument this morning. She makes angry comments about other drivers on the road. She jumps a red light, saying 'No-one will be around this time of the morning'. Character 3 is playing music (perhaps rap style performed by a member of the cast forming his car.) He sees character 1 crossing his path, and shouts, 'I can't stop!' Character 1 shouts, 'Oh no! Another car - I'm gonna hit him!'. Sound effects can be used here to create the skidding noises, engine noises and sound of breaking glass. The lights go out. Silence. General lights come back up to reveal two bodies lying on the 'road'. Voices are heard saying things such as:'She drove straight through the red light!' 'The other driver didn't have a chance!' 'She was going too fast!' 'Are they still alive?' Everything sounds confused and chaotic. Eventually a siren is heard as the lights fade down.

Deciding on the ending is important too. Do you want to finish using the same sequence as at the start? This could focus the audience's mind on the characters and how they came together in a fateful manner. Do you want to have character 3 in a wheelchair - facing his life without hope of walking again? Perhaps using a monologue to tell the audience how he feels? Do you want the families of each of the characters trying to come to terms with what has happened? The final scene must have impact, and make clear the whole point that you intend for your drama.

Images can be useful in your portfolio for explaining a point or illustrating what you did in your drama.Images can be useful in your portfolio - for explaining to the points you make, or help make your descriptions come to life. This Revision Bite will help you make your images work well in your portfolio. These are not good reasons for using images, and you will not gain marks through doing this. If you use images for the reasons above, you're likely to gain extra marks. However, remember to analyse each image carefully, providing written explanation or annotations. Remember, images don't just refer to photographs - you can use sketches, drawings, stick men diagrams or any type of image, so long as you use it to make a point.

This is a still-image of our work when we were exploring the abuse of prisoners in Abu Ghraib prison. We were trying to communicate that the prisoner was being intimidated by two US soldiers, and that this was a harrowing experience for the prisoner. I feel we should have arranged the image better, so that the proxemics could more easily show what was happening. If the prisoner had been placed facing the audience it would have been easier to see his expression, and if the two soldiers had been placed a little upstage on each side of the prisoner, we could have shown the expressions of everyone - and the face of one soldier character would not have been hidden by their hair. The prisoner should have looked more intimidated than is shown in the actor's body language - she looked too relaxed to communicate the terror the prisoner must have felt. The candidate has written well about the image, and has included some evaluative remarks that point out the shortcomings of the group's work. It is clear that the candidate realizes how the work could have been improved, and this demonstrates understanding of the process.

During the phase of the work when we were developing scenes to show the abuse in Abu Ghraib prison, we were working to show how the soldiers were intimidated by their own superior officers, because of the abuse that they were investigating. We wanted to show how by making the officer stand behind the soldier, with the soldier too scared to turn around, we were able to show the status of the officer. We could also show the way in which he could signal his feelings to the audience, without the prisoner seeing any facial expressions. This would also leave the soldier able to show his own anxiety in the situation, through his body language and facial expressions. The actor here was able to signal this well. Here the image is commented on by the candidate, and it is clear that the proxemics are such that the candidates were able to heighten the sense of anxiety in the scene, and to show this to the audience. The candidate has explained well the reasons for their staging of this sequence.

This image shows our work at a point when we, the staff in the care home, were taking the old lady away from her room to clean her up after she had spilled her food. We wanted to show that the staff can be harsh in their treatment of the elderly residents of the home and that they don't treat some of their residents as they state in their brochures. As it is shown here, the staff members look as if they are not caring, and I think that this would be clear to an audience. I think we were able to show that the old woman looks scared and that the staff look uncaring about her fears. The girl playing the old lady is showing through her facial expression and body language that she is scared and we planned that the audience would be shocked by this treatment of her. The comment by the candidate has first been put into context, so that the situation is more understandable. The evaluation and reflection on his / her work illustrates some strong aspects, and others where the candidate feels that improvements could be made. This indicates that the candidate has a good level of knowledge and understanding.
